The '''2010 SEC Softball Tournament''' was held at Bogle Park on the campus of the [[University of Arkansas]] in [[Fayetteville, Arkansas]] on May 13 through May 15, 2010. The [[Alabama Crimson Tide softball|Alabama Crimson Tide]] won the tournament for the 4th time in their history, and received the conference's automatic bid to the [[2010 NCAA Division I Softball Tournament]]. ==Tournament== {{8TeamBracket | RD1=Quarterfinals
May 13th | RD2=Semifinals
May 14th | RD3=Finals
May 15th | group1= | group2= | RD1-seed1=3 | RD1-team1='''LSU''' | RD1-score1='''2 | RD1-seed2=6 | RD1-team2=Kentucky | RD1-score2=1 | RD1-seed3=2 | RD1-team3='''[[2010 Florida Gators softball season|Florida]]''' | RD1-score3=9 | RD1-seed4=7 | RD1-team4=Auburn | RD1-score4=1 | RD1-seed5=1 | RD1-team5= '''[[2010 Alabama Crimson Tide softball season|Alabama]]''' | RD1-score5=9 | RD1-seed6=8 | RD1-team6=Arkansas | RD1-score6=0 | RD1-seed7=4 | RD1-team7=Georgia | RD1-score7=4 | RD1-seed8=5 | RD1-team8='''Tennessee''' | RD1-score8='''6''' | RD2-seed1=3 | RD2-team1='''LSU''' | RD2-score1='''9''' | RD2-seed2=2 | RD2-team2=Florida | RD2-score2=1 | RD2-seed3=1 | RD2-team3='''Alabama''' | RD2-score3=4 | RD2-seed4=5 | RD2-team4=Tennessee | RD2-score4=3 | RD3-seed1=3 | RD3-team1=LSU | RD3-score1=4 | RD3-seed2=1 | RD3-team2='''Alabama''' | RD3-score2='''5''' }} ==See also== *[[Women's College World Series]] *[[NCAA Division I Softball Championship]] *[[SEC Softball Tournament]] *[[SEC Tournament]] ==External links== *[http://www.arkansasrazorbacks.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=6100&ATCLID=204910205 2010 SEC Softball Tournament] ==References== {{reflist}} {{SEC Softball Tournament}} {{Southeastern Conference softball navbox}} [[Category:SEC Softball Tournament]] [[Category:2010 Southeastern Conference softball season]] [[Category:2010 in sports in Arkansas|SEC Softball]] [[Category:Softball in Arkansas]] {{softball-competition-stub}} {{Arkansas-sport-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox rugby league football match |year = |title = Battle of Brookvale |image = |imagesize = |alt = |home = Manly-Warringah
Sea Eagles |away = Melbourne
Storm |home_abbr = MAN {{leagueicon|Manly|16}} |away_abbr = MEL {{leagueicon|Melbourne|16}} |home_half1 = 14 |home_half2 = 4 |home_total = 18 |away_half1 = 0 |away_half2 = 4 |away_total = 4 |date = 26 August 2011 |stadium = [[Brookvale Oval]] |location = [[Brookvale, New South Wales|Brookvale]], [[New South Wales]] |MoM_title = |MoM = |anthem_title = |anthem = |referee = [[Shayne Hayne]] |referee2 = Gavin Badger |attendance = 20,414 |network = [[Nine Network]] |commentators = [[Ray Warren]] |commentators2 = [[Peter Sterling]] |commentators3 = [[Phil Gould]] |commentators4 = [[Wally Lewis]] |tournaments = [[2011 NRL season]] |last = |next = }} The '''Battle of Brookvale''' was the unofficial name given to the [[2011 NRL season results#Round 25|Round 25, 2011]] [[National Rugby League]] (NRL) match between the [[Manly-Warringah Sea Eagles]] and [[Melbourne Storm]], played at [[Brookvale Oval]] on 26 August 2011. A number of incidents in the first half led to some fights breaking out all over the ground, eventually turning into a five-minute brawl involving all players on the ground. Following the brawl, Manly went on to win the match 18–4, on its way to finishing second on the premiership ladder. Several players faced charges at the [[NRL Judiciary]] with suspensions and fines being handed out. ==Background== {{see also|Manly–Melbourne NRL rivalry}} The Manly-Warringah Sea Eagles and the Melbourne Storm have, in recent years, engaged in a modern-day rivalry which is amongst one of the most recognised in the National Rugby League today. In seven of eight seasons between 2006 and 2013 (except 2010), at least one of these two teams featured in the Grand Final, and, in the five of six seasons between 2007 and 2012, one of these teams won the premiership, though the Storm's 2007 and 2009 titles (the former of which was won by defeating Manly in the Grand Final) were later stripped from the club as a result of [[Melbourne Storm salary cap breach|salary cap breaches]] exposed by the NRL in 2010.{{cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/rugby-league/league-news/melbourne-storm-stripped-of-everything-20100422-tfy6.html|title=Melbourne Storm stripped of everything|last=Munro|first=Ian|date=23 April 2010|publisher=The Age|accessdate=23 April 2010}} The height of this rivalry came with the two clubs' meetings in the [[2007 NRL Grand Final|2007]] and [[2008 NRL Grand Final|2008]] NRL Grand Finals. Melbourne defeated Manly 34–8 to win the 2007 title, whilst Manly reversed the result and won by a record 40–0 scoreline in 2008. They have also featured in two finals matches, with Melbourne winning both by the scoreline of 40–12 in the 2009 qualifying final and the 2012 preliminary final. This was to be the first match attended by [[David Gallop]] of either side since suspending [[Brett Stewart (rugby league)|Brett Stewart]] from the first four weeks of the 2009 season for a sexual assault charge for which he would later be exonerated, and since stripping the Storm of two premiership titles and three minor premiership titles for salary cap breaches; extra security was hired for his presence at the game.{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/sport/security-for-david-gallop-at-brookvale/story-e6frg7mf-1226120765776|title=Security for David Gallop at Brookvale|last=Honeysett|first=Stuart|date=24 August 2011|work=[[The Australian]]|accessdate=11 November 2011}} ==During the match== ===Lead-up to the brawl=== [[Kieran Foran]] scored the first try of the match for the Sea Eagles early in the first half, after [[Billy Slater]] misjudged a ball which had bounced in the Sea Eagles' in-goal area. In the 22nd minute of the match, Manly winger [[David Williams (rugby league)|David Williams]] suffered a neck injury, which resulted in play being suspended whilst he was carried off the stretcher. In stark contrast to what would come later in the game, Billy Slater who had tackled Williams (Williams had hit Slater's chest with the top of his head which caused the injury), realising there was a neck injury, cradled Williams and wouldn't let him move or his Manly team mates move him until the medical staff arrived.[http://www.abc.net.au/news/2011-08-26/sea-eagles-rout-melbourne-at-brookvale/2857914 Sea Eagles rout Storm in fiery clash], ''ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)'', 26 August 2011{{cite news|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/sport/news/article.cfm?c_id=4&objectid=10747888|title=NRL: Neck injury ends Williams' season|date=29 August 2011|work=[[New Zealand Herald]]|accessdate=11 November 2011}} ===The brawl=== Shortly after the Williams injury, Melbourne interchange forward [[Ryan Hinchcliffe]] conceded a penalty when he struck Manly's [[Darcy Lussick]] close to the Sea Eagles' line.[http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/sport/nrl/sea-eagles-v-storm-live/story-e6frexnr-1226123075124 Manly Sea Eagles beat Melbourne Storm 18-4 in NRL round 25], ''The Daily Telegraph'', 27 August 2011 This resulted in a brawl between the two players, following which [[Adam Blair]] and [[Glenn Stewart]] were sin-binned for joining in. On their way to the dressing rooms, a major brawl erupted between Blair and Stewart, which involved players and officials from both sides; the two subsequently had their sin-bin punishments upgraded to a [[red card (sports)|send off]], meaning they would take no further part in the match.{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/rugby-league/league-news/battle-of-brookie-set-to-take-toll-on-big-guns-title-assault-20110826-1jeto.html|title=Battle of Brookie set to take toll on big guns' title assault|last=Jackson|first=Glenn|date=27 August 2011|work=[[Sydney Morning Herald]]|accessdate=11 November 2011}} Apart from the main culprits, many other players, including [[Brett Stewart (rugby league)|Brett Stewart]], also joined in the brawl, with Stewart claiming that he was acting in self-defence of his older brother. Officials and trainers from both clubs also joined in the brawl.[http://www.foxsports.com.au/league/nrl-premiership/no-less-than-12-players-and-officials-from-manly-and-melbourne-storm-will-be-scrutinised-by-the-nrl/story-fn2mcuj6-1226124189530 No less than 12 players and officials from Manly and Melbourne Storm will be scrutinized by the NRL], ''Fox Sports Australia'', 29 August 2011 ===After the brawl=== Manly captain [[Jamie Lyon]] converted a penalty goal from the Hinchcliffe penalty from right in front, as the Sea Eagles' lead stretched to 8–0. The Sea Eagles would eventually win 18–4 with a late [[Billy Slater]] try preventing the Storm from being held scoreless for the first time since the 2008 NRL Grand Final. ==Teams== {| style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto" |- style="background:#eee;" !align="center" width="136" style="border: 3px solid silver; background: maroon; color: white"|Manly-Warringah

background:#eee;"|[[Fullback (rugby league)|FB]]|| style="text-align:center;"|[[Billy Slater]] |- | style="text-align:center;"|[[Michael Robertson (rugby league)|Michael Robertson]]|| style="text-align:center; background:#eee;"|Coach|| style="text-align:center;"|[[Craig Bellamy (rugby league)|Craig Bellamy]] |} {{-}} ==Match details== {{rugbyleaguebox | date = 26 August 2011 | time = 7:30pm (AEST) | team1 = [[Manly-Warringah Sea Eagles]] {{leagueicon|Manly|16}} | score = 18 – 4 | report = [http://www.rugbyleagueproject.org/seasons/nrl-2011/round-25/manly-warringah-vs-melbourne/summary.html Manly-Warringah va Melbourne] | team2 = {{leagueicon|Melbourne|16}} [[Melbourne Storm]] | points1 = '''Tries:'''

'''Goals:'''
[[Gareth Widdop]] (0/1) | stadium = [[Brookvale Oval]], [[Sydney]] | attendance = 20,414 | referee = [[Shayne Hayne]], Gavin Badger | manofmatch = }} ==Judiciary== No fewer than ten players and two officials from both clubs were later charged by the [[NRL Judiciary]] for their roles in the brawl, with both Glenn Stewart and Adam Blair referred straight to the judiciary. Additionally, each club was fined $50,000 from the NRL.[http://www.sportsnewsfirst.com.au/articles/2011/08/29/mass-charges-after-battle-of-brookvale/ Mass charges after Battle of Brookvale] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131112083811/http://www.sportsnewsfirst.com.au/articles/2011/08/29/mass-charges-after-battle-of-brookvale/ |date=November 12, 2013 }}, ''Sports News First'', 29 August 2011{{cite news|url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/sport/nrl/live-stream-nrl-boss-david-gallop-delivers-his-verdict-on-friday-nights-battle-of-brookvale-between-manly-and-storm/story-e6frexnr-1226124470466|title=Manly Sea Eagles and Melbourne Storm fined $50,000 each and 10 players charged by NRL judiciary after 'Battle of Brookie'|last=Ritchie|first=Dean|date=29 August 2011|work=[[The Daily Telegraph (Sydney)]]|accessdate=11 November 2011}} For their parts, Glenn Stewart and Adam Blair were both banned for three and five matches respectively.[http://www.smh.com.au/rugby-league/league-news/fight-night-stewart-blair-out-for-season-20110829-1jigt.html Fight night: Stewart, Blair out for season], ''Sydney Morning Herald'', 30 August 2011 The charges and outcomes were as follows: ===Manly=== {| class="wikitable" |- style="background:#efefef;" ! style="width:100pt;"| Player ! style="width:100pt;"| Charge ! style="width:100pt;"| Grade ! style="width:100pt;"| Outcome |- |[[Glenn Stewart]] |{{nowrap|Contrary Conduct – fighting}} |Referred |{{nowrap|Three-match suspension}} |- |[[Darcy Lussick]] |Contrary Conduct |4 |{{nowrap|Three-match suspension[http://www.theaustralian.com.au/sport/darcy-lussicks-brawl-gloating-draws-david-gallops-ire/story-e6frg7mf-1226126799764 Darcy Lussick's brawl gloating draws David Gallop's ire], ''The Australian'', 1 September 2011}} |- |[[Brett Stewart (rugby league)|Brett Stewart]] |Contrary Conduct |3 |One-match suspension |- |[[Kieran Foran]] |Contrary Conduct |2 |One-match suspension[http://www.theaustralian.com.au/sport/ban-halts-manlys-playmaker-kieran-foran-from-facing-darren-lockyer/story-e6frg7mf-1226125901748 Ban halts Manly's playmaker Kieran Foran from facing Darren Lockyer], ''The Australian'', 31 August 2011 |- |[[Michael Robertson (rugby league)|Michael Robertson]] |Contrary Conduct |1 | |} ===Melbourne=== {| class="wikitable" |- style="background:#efefef;" ! style="width:100pt;"| Player ! style="width:100pt;"| Charge ! style="width:100pt;"| Grade ! style="width:100pt;"| Outcome |- |rowspan="2"|[[Adam Blair]] |{{nowrap|Contrary Conduct – fighting}} |Referred |rowspan="2"|{{nowrap|Five-match suspension[http://www.sportsnewsfirst.com.au/articles/2011/08/31/blair-banned-for-five-for-battle-of-brookvale/ Blair banned for five for Battle of Brookvale] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131112083802/http://www.sportsnewsfirst.com.au/articles/2011/08/31/blair-banned-for-five-for-battle-of-brookvale/ |date=November 12, 2013 }}, ''Sports News First'', 31 August 2011}} |- |Striking |2 |- |[[Sisa Waqa]] |Detrimental Conduct |2 | |- |[[Bryan Norrie]] |Detrimental Conduct |1 | |- |[[Jaiman Lowe]] |Detrimental Conduct |1 | |- |[[Sika Manu]] |Detrimental Conduct |1 | |} ==Reaction== Then-NRL CEO [[David Gallop]] condemned the actions of both teams, saying: {{quote|''The sight of so many players from both teams fighting, of people running in and leaving the bench area, was a horrendous look for the game.''| [[David Gallop]] }} Despite the spiteful nature of the match, Melbourne's Billy Slater won universal praise for his actions after the neck injury to Manly winger David Williams. ==See also== *[[List of sporting scandals]] *[[Line in the sand match]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== * [http://www.rugbyleagueproject.org/seasons/nrl-2011/round-25/manly-warringah-vs-melbourne/stats.html Match Statistics on Rugby League Project] * {{YouTube|id=rQHXv0W1Los|title=Manly V Storm FIGHT [HD] 2011 (Glen Stewart V Adam Blair)}} {{Manly-Warringah Sea Eagles}} {{Melbourne Storm}} [[Category:Manly Warringah Sea Eagles matches]] [[Category:Rugby league club matches]] [[Category:Brawls in team sports]] [[Category:Melbourne Storm matches]] [[Category:August 2011 sports events]] [[Category:Sports scandals in Australia]]

101,821 (2010–present){{cite web |title=Facilities: Bryant–Denny Stadium|url=https://rolltide.com/sports/2016/6/10/facilities-bryant-denny-html.aspx|publisher=University of Alabama Department of Intercollegiate Athletics|accessdate=February 3, 2011}} }} {{Location map |USA |relief = 1 |label = Tuscaloosa  |lat = 33.208 |long = -87.55 |caption = Location in Tuscaloosa, Alabama |marksize = 5 |position = top |float = |background = |width = 250 }} {{Location map |USA Alabama |relief = 1 |label = Tuscaloosa |lat = 33.208 |long = -87.55 |caption = Location in [[Alabama]] |marksize = 5 |float = |background = |width = 130 }} '''Bryant–Denny Stadium''' is an outdoor stadium in the [[Southeastern United States|southeastern]] United States, on the campus of the [[University of Alabama]] in [[Tuscaloosa, Alabama|Tuscaloosa]]. It is the home field of the [[Alabama Crimson Tide]] [[Alabama Crimson Tide football|football team]] of the [[Southeastern Conference]] (SEC). Opened {{Time ago|1929}} in [[1929 Alabama Crimson Tide football team|1929]], it was originally named Denny Stadium in honor of [[George H. Denny]], the school's president from 1912 to 1932. In 1975, the [[Alabama Legislature|state legislature]] added longtime head coach and alumnus [[Bear Bryant|Paul "Bear" Bryant]] to the stadium's name. Bryant led the Tide for seven more seasons, through [[1982 Alabama Crimson Tide football team|1982]], and is one of the few in [[NCAA Division I|Division I]] to have coached in a venue bearing his name. With a [[seating capacity]] of 101,821, it is the fourth-largest stadium in the Southeastern Conference, the [[List of American football stadiums by capacity|seventh largest]] stadium in the United States and the [[List of stadiums by capacity|eighth largest]] stadium in the world. ==Construction== The replacement for [[Denny Field (Alabama)|Denny Field]], Denny Stadium opened in [[1929 Alabama Crimson Tide football team|1929]], with 6,000 in attendance for a 55–0 victory over [[Mississippi College Choctaws|Mississippi College]] on September 28.{{cite news |title=Alabama Gets 6 Touchdowns by Swift Play in First Half|first=Donald|last=Tubb|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=29A-AAAAIBAJ&sjid=gkwMAAAAIBAJ&pg=5474%2C5147177|newspaper=[[The Tuscaloosa News]]|date=September 29, 1929|accessdate=February 1, 2011}} It was officially dedicated the following week at [[Homecoming]] ceremonies against [[Ole Miss Rebels football|Ole Miss]], a 22–7 Crimson Tide victory.{{cite news |title=12,000 See Alabama Win, 22–7|first=Donald|last=Tubb|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=nIA-AAAAIBAJ&sjid=BkwMAAAAIBAJ&pg=5886%2C252468|newspaper=[[The Tuscaloosa News]]|date=October 6, 1929|accessdate=February 1, 2011}} Originally, the stadium had a capacity of 12,000—the lower half of the current stadium's east grandstand. However, President Denny initially envisioned a full bowl stadium capable of seating 66,000.{{cite news |title=Denny Stadium|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ftY-AAAAIBAJ&sjid=10wMAAAAIBAJ&pg=6504%2C4372156|newspaper=[[The Tuscaloosa News]]|date=October 8, 1937|accessdate=April 12, 2012|page=4}} Before the [[1937 Alabama Crimson Tide football team|1937]] season, permanent seats were built along the east sideline, increasing the capacity to 24,000. Further expansions in [[1946 Alabama Crimson Tide football team|1946]] (bleachers in both end zones), [[Alabama Crimson Tide football team|1961]] (new seats in west grandstand), and [[1966 Alabama Crimson Tide football team|1966]] (both end zones fully enclosed, new seats in east grandstand) raised capacity to 31,000, 43,000, and 60,210, respectively.{{cite news |title=Brushing Up|first=Mike|last=Land|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=vDUdAAAAIBAJ&sjid=paUEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6296%2C3052438|newspaper=[[The Tuscaloosa News]]|date=July 15, 1983|accessdate=February 12, 2012|page=11}} An upper deck was added to the west side in [[1988 Alabama Crimson Tide football team|1988]] and raised the seating by nearly 10,000 to 70,123. During the construction, the Crimson Tide played its entire [[1987 Alabama Crimson Tide football team|1987]] home schedule at [[Legion Field]] in [[Birmingham, Alabama|Birmingham]], {{convert|57|mi|-1}} northeast of Bryant-Denny.{{cite news |title=Renovation at Bryant–Denny Welcome News|first=Andrew|last=Carroll|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=H4o0AAAAIBAJ&sjid=lKUEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6698%2C6277559|newspaper=[[The Tuscaloosa News]]|date=January 25, 1987|accessdate=February 21, 2012|page=2F}} ===East upper deck (1998)=== In September 1995, the University of Alabama System Board of Trustees approved the construction of the east upper deck.{{cite news |title=Stadium Deal Gets Approval |first=Richard|last=Powell|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=7TsdAAAAIBAJ&sjid=MaYEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4889%2C5084886|newspaper=[[The Tuscaloosa News]]|date=September 16, 1995|accessdate=February 5, 2011|page=1A}} Designed by the architectural firm of [[Heery International|Heery-Chambless-Adams]], the construction was financed by the university and $4.65 million from the city of Tuscaloosa, the city of [[Northport, Alabama|Northport]], and [[Tuscaloosa County, Alabama|Tuscaloosa County]]. The localities contributed to construction costs in return for the university pledging to move all Crimson Tide home games to Bryant–Denny and not play any at Legion Field. The new upper deck provided 10,000 additional bleacher seats and 81 [[Luxury box|skyboxes]] on two levels—63 16-seat and 18 24-seat capacity boxes.{{cite news |title=Skyboxes a Popular Addition to Stadium|first=Cecil|last=Hurt|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=3iEfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=UqYEAAAAIBAJ&dq=skybox%20news&pg=6747%2C1890841|newspaper=[[The Tuscaloosa News]]|date=October 10, 1998|accessdate=February 5, 2011|page=8C}} In 1999, four additional skyboxes were built to bring the total number of skyboxes to 85. A [[JumboTron]] scoreboard with video display capabilities was erected in the south end zone and was at the time the largest in collegiate sports.{{cite news |title=Jumbo View: Bama's Big-Screen Scoreboard is the Largest in College Football|first=Tommy|last=Deas|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=XUmZziu-z7kC&dat=19981010&printsec=frontpage&hl=en|newspaper=[[The Tuscaloosa News]]|date=October 10, 1998|accessdate=September 17, 2018|page=C1}} Additionally, a new east side entrance tower, a brick facade and reception areas for the Scholarship and A-Club level patrons was also added during the 1998 expansion. The stadium's eastern upper deck was opened in [[1998 Alabama Crimson Tide football team|1998]] and raised its official [[seating capacity]] to 83,818 at a final cost of $35 million for the addition.{{cite news |title=So What Else Is New?|first=Robert|last=DeWitt|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=4UogAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Z6YEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5652%2C541265|newspaper=[[The Tuscaloosa News]]|date=September 5, 1998|accessdate=February 5, 2011}} The newly expanded venue debuted on September 5, and Alabama defeated [[BYU Cougars football|BYU]] 38–31 as running back [[Shaun Alexander]] set a Tide single-game record with five touchdowns.{{cite news |title=Alexander spearheads Tide shootout |first=Cecil |last=Hurt |page=C1 |newspaper=Tuscaloosa News |date=September 6, 1998}} ===North end zone expansion (2006)=== [[File:Bryant-Denny Stadium by Highsmith 01.jpg|thumb|left|View of the north end zone of the stadium exterior and the Walk of Champions]] Following the [[2004 Alabama Crimson Tide football team|2004]] season, the university spent approximately $47 million on an expansion to the north end zone, which was completed days before the 2006 opener against Hawaii. It added a new upper deck to the North end zone area, complete with three different levels of skyboxes, which collectively are known as "The Zone", which brought the number of skyboxes in the stadium to 123. Two large display screens by [[Daktronics]] were placed in each corner of the north end zone, and [[Liquid crystal display|LCD]] ribbon screens, {{convert|3.5|ft}} tall by {{convert|422|ft}} wide, were placed along the front edge of the east and west upper decks. Massive changes were made to the grounds of the north side of the stadium with the addition of a [[:Category:Walks of fame|Walk]] of Champions. Building the Walk of Champions required the demolition of the [[Delta Kappa Epsilon]] fraternity house and the [[Grading (engineering)|grading]] of the hill it sat upon. The Walk of Champions comprises a brick plaza leading from University Boulevard to the north end zone entrances. The plaza features 16 granite monuments set into the walkway commemorating the Crimson Tide's SEC and national championship teams throughout the years. Along the west side of the plaza are five roughly {{convert|2000|lb|adj=on}}, {{convert|9|ft|adj=on}} tall bronze statues, one for each Alabama football coach who has led the Crimson Tide to a national championship. Each statue has a semicircular wall behind it bearing the coach's name and the year(s) that he led the team to a national championship. The first four statues, unveiled during the opening in 2006, included [[Wallace Wade]], [[Frank Thomas (American football)|Frank Thomas]], [[Bear Bryant|Paul "Bear" Bryant]], and [[Gene Stallings]].{{cite news |title=Bryant–Denny Undergoing Monumental Change|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1891&dat=20060629&id=qp1GAAAAIBAJ&sjid=3P0MAAAAIBAJ&pg=2100,2884194|newspaper=[[The Gadsden Times]]|agency=[[Associated Press]]|date=June 29, 2006|accessdate=December 25, 2012}} The fifth statue, that of [[Nick Saban]], was unveiled prior to the A-Day game on April 16, 2011. It commemorates Saban guiding Alabama to its 13th National Championship with a 37–21 win over the [[Texas Longhorns football|Texas Longhorns]]. [[File:BDSNEExpansion.jpg|thumb|The north end zone entrance in 2007, with commemorative Alabama players statuary group on the left.]] Finally, there is a bronze statuary group of two anonymous Alabama football players at the entrance to the north end zone, with the one on the left holding a large Alabama Crimson Tide flag upright on a flagpole. This player is wearing the number 18 and a helmet, with the player on the right wearing the number 92 and pointing into the distance. The jersey numbers represent 1892, the first season of Crimson Tide football. The north end zone was opened for the [[2006 Alabama Crimson Tide football team|2006]] season opener versus [[2006 Hawaii Warriors football team|Hawaii]], which set a new record attendance of 92,138. The Crimson Tide was victorious, 25–17.{{cite web |title=Late Defensive Stand Helps Tide Hold Off Game Hawaii|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/recap?gameId=262450333|work=[[ESPN]]|agency=[[Associated Press]]|date=September 2, 2006|accessdate=October 7, 2008}} ===South end zone expansion (2010)=== [[File:Bryant-Denny south 2010-09-04 Altered.jpg|thumb|left|Exterior of the new south end zone in 2010.]] The University of Alabama Board of Trustees approved a study for further expansion of Bryant–Denny on September 19, 2008.{{cite news |title=UA Trustees Approve Unitial Study for Bryant-Denny stadium Expansion|first=Kyle|last=Fondren|url=http://www.tuscaloosanews.com/article/20080919/WVUA01/809190297|newspaper=[[The Tuscaloosa News]]|date=September 19, 2008|accessdate=September 17, 2018}} The Physical Properties Committee of the University of Alabama Board of Trustees heard a presentation from the UA athletic department on November 13, 2008 regarding the proposed $80.6 million expansion of the south end zone upper deck and suite level of Bryant–Denny Stadium. The proposed expansion would bring the stadium's capacity to approximately 101,600, therefore making it the second largest stadium in the Southeastern Conference (SEC), and the fifth largest stadium in college football.{{cite web |title=Offeseason Pigskinpalooza: College Football's Megastadiums|first=D. J.|last=Gallo|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/page2/story?page=gallo/100715_nfl_college_football_offseason|work=[[ESPN]]|date=July 15, 2010|accessdate=November 18, 2010}} The committee unanimously approved the project to move into the third of four stages, the fourth being final approval to begin construction.{{cite news |title=$80.6M Budget Approved for Stadium Expansion|first=Brett|last=Bralley|url=http://www.cw.ua.edu/80.6m_budget_approved_for_stadium_expansion|newspaper=[[The Crimson White]]|location=University of Alabama|date=November 14, 2008|accessdate=November 18, 2008}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}} On February 6, 2009, the university's Board of Trustees voted unanimously and without discussion to give the final approval for construction to commence on the south end zone expansion. With the approval of the Board of Trustees, construction began in the Spring of 2009 and continued throughout the 2009 football season.{{cite news |title=It's Official|first=Ian|last=Rapport|url=http://blog.al.com/rapsheet/2009/02/its_official_bryantdenny_will.html|newspaper=[[The Birmingham News]]|date=February 6, 2009|accessdate=February 6, 2009}}{{cite press release |title=Board of Trustees Officially Approves Bryant–Denny Stadium South End Zone Expansion Project|url=http://www.rolltide.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/020609aaa.html|publisher=University of Alabama Department of Intercollegiate Athletics|date=February 6, 2009|accessdate=February 7, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090414004253/http://www.rolltide.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/020609aaa.html|archivedate=April 14, 2009}} The expansion was finished in time for the first game of the team's [[2010 Alabama Crimson Tide football team|2010 season]]. ''The Tuscaloosa News'' reported on April 17, 2009 that due to the economic climate and resultant lowered construction costs, the stadium expansion cost $15 million less than expected, coming in around $65.6 million.{{cite news |title=UA Stadium Expansion Cheaper Than Expected|first=Adam|last=Jones|url=http://www.tuscaloosanews.com/article/20090417/NEWS/904169969|newspaper=[[The Tuscaloosa News]]|date=April 17, 2009|accessdate=April 19, 2009}} [[File:Bryant Denny 2 9-4-10.jpg|thumb|right|Newly expanded south end zone of Bryant Denny with new LED screens]] The expanded south end zone now includes a two level South Zone club with a total of 1,700 seats and 36 skyboxes to bring the total number of skyboxes in Bryant–Denny Stadium to 159, as well as an 8,500 seat upper deck. The entire stadium's audio/visual system was upgraded to include two new video boards in both corners of the south end zone.{{cite press release |title=Mal Moore Announces Request For Approval Of South End Zone Project|url=http://www.rolltide.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/020309aaa.html|publisher=University of Alabama Department of Intercollegiate Athletics|date=February 6, 2009|accessdate=February 7, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120909034948/http://www.rolltide.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/020309aaa.html|archivedate=September 9, 2012}} Prior to the [[2009 Alabama Crimson Tide football team|2009]] season, the large south scoreboard was disassembled to make way for the construction of the new stadium expansion. During this process, some welding equipment started a fire that burned the inside of the scoreboard.{{cite news |title=Small Fire Strikes Bryant–Denny Stadium Scoreboad|first=Gentry|last=Estes|url=http://blog.al.com/bamabeat/2009/02/small_fire_strikes_bryantdenny.html|newspaper=[[Press-Register]]|location=Mobile|date=February 19, 2009|accessdate=November 22, 2009}} Also, during this time, four new play clocks and down/distance indicators were installed (one behind each corner of the end zones) and a new LED game clock was placed behind the south goalpost. The expansion was completed in mid-summer [[2010 Alabama Crimson Tide football team|2010]] and held an official capacity of 101,821 making it the fifth largest college football stadium in the country. The new seats were all sold out quickly for the entire 2010 football season. In the future, the new expansion will include stores and other extras on the bottom of the end zone. The University is planning a full stadium expansion with construction expand to begin at the start of the 2020 season. ==Football lore== Since its opening in [[1929 Alabama Crimson Tide football team|1929]] through [[2010 Alabama Crimson Tide football team|2010]], the Crimson Tide owns a {{Winning percentage|212|50|3|record=y}} record at Bryant–Denny Stadium.{{cite web |url=http://grfx.cstv.com/photos/schools/alab/sports/m-footbl/auto_pdf/history-awards.pdf |title=Bryant–Denny Stadium Year-By-Year Record |work=2010 Alabama Football Media Guide |publisher=University of Alabama Athletic Department |page=138 |accessdate=February 3, 2011 |format=PDF |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110523102902/http://grfx.cstv.com/photos/schools/alab/sports/m-footbl/auto_pdf/history-awards.pdf |archivedate=May 23, 2011 |df= }} Bear Bryant is the leader in wins at the stadium, with an all-time record of {{Winning percentage|72|2|record=y}} in his quarter century as Tide head coach. [[File:WalkofChampions 2010-11-26.jpg|thumb|left|The Walk of Champions prior to the 2010 [[Iron Bowl]].]] Despite its success at Bryant–Denny, most of Alabama's "home" football history from the 1920s through the 1980s occurred at Birmingham's Legion Field.{{cite web |title=2010 Alabama Football Media Guide|trans-title=Alabama Football at Legion Field|url=http://grfx.cstv.com/photos/schools/alab/sports/m-footbl/auto_pdf/history-awards.pdf|publisher=University of Alabama Department of Intercollegiate Athletics|accessdate=February 3, 2011|pages=141–142|format=PDF|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110523102902/http://grfx.cstv.com/photos/schools/alab/sports/m-footbl/auto_pdf/history-awards.pdf|archivedate=May 23, 2011}} Well into the late 1990s, the higher capacity Legion Field hosted most of Alabama's important home games, including the [[Iron Bowl]] with rival [[Auburn Tigers football|Auburn]], which was considered a neutral site from 1948 through 1987. The Crimson Tide hosted Tennessee in odd-numbered years in Birmingham until 1999, and LSU in even-numbered years from 1964 through 1986, except for 1980. Usually, Bryant–Denny hosted three or four games per season, mostly non-conference games, although the Tide always played Mississippi State in Tuscaloosa, save for 1987, due to the close distance between Tuscaloosa and [[Starkville, Mississippi|Starkville]]. However, in 1998, when Bryant–Denny was expanded to a capacity exceeding Legion Field, the more important home games started to move to Bryant–Denny, culminating with the move of the Tennessee series to Tuscaloosa in 1999 and the Iron Bowl a year later.{{cite news |title=Vols Due in Fall, AU in 2000|first=Cecil|last=Hurt|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=6ckdAAAAIBAJ&sjid=VqYEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6026%2C631746|newspaper=[[The Tuscaloosa News]]|date=March 6, 1999|accessdate=February 3, 2011|page=1}} From 1998 to 2003, Alabama continued to play two or three minor games in Birmingham. Finally, in 2003, Alabama played its final game at Legion Field against the [[South Florida Bulls]], and now Bryant–Denny is the sole home of Alabama football. [[File:BDSfromDennyChimes.JPG|thumb|View of the northern side of the stadium and [[Tailgate party|tailgaters]] as seen from the [[Denny Chimes]] vicinity of [[University of Alabama Quad|The Quad]] in 2008.]] However, despite the majority of past big games being played at Legion Field, Bryant–Denny Stadium has hosted many memorable games, such as the 1994 shootout between Alabama's [[Jay Barker]] and Georgia's [[Eric Zeier]], Marvin Constant's goal-line stop against [[1999 LSU Tigers football team|LSU]] quarterback Josh Booty as time expired in 1999, [[Tyrone Prothro]]'s reception over the back of Southern Miss defensive back Jasper Faulk in 2005, a 31–3 victory over No. 5 Florida in 2005, the [[Roman Harper]]-forced fumble against [[2005 Tennessee Volunteers football team|Tennessee]] in 2005 that helped the Crimson Tide to victory, Alabama's 36–0 shutout victory against Auburn in 2008 thus breaking the six-game losing streak and first ever [[Iron Bowl]] victory in Bryant–Denny Stadium, and [[Terrence Cody]]'s field goal block against [[2009 Tennessee Volunteers football team|Tennessee]] as time expired in 2009. In recent years, Bryant–Denny Stadium has become a feared place to play again. Also Bryant-Denny has been put on many lists ranking it one of the best places to watch football. [[NCAA Football 11]] ranked Alabama's Bryant–Denny as the fourth toughest place to play in the nation and third in the SEC behind [[Ben Hill Griffin Stadium|Florida]] and [[Tiger Stadium (LSU)|LSU]]. ''Sporting News'' ranks it first while Bleacher Report has it ranked as the 5th toughest and the 2nd best stadium in the country.{{cite web |title=College Football Rankings: 25 Best College Football Game Day Experiences|first=Wes|last=O'Donnell|url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/592904-25-best-college-football-game-day-experiences/page/25|work=[[Bleacher Report]]|date=February 1, 2011|accessdate=September 14, 2018}} ==Field design== {{Panorama |image = File:Bryant-Denny 10-22-11.jpg |fullwidth = 7136 |fullheight = 2392 |caption = The interior of Bryant–Denny Stadium (south end zone, left) during a [[2011 Alabama Crimson Tide football team|2011]] Alabama game versus [[2011 Tennessee Volunteers football team|Tennessee]]. |height = 200 }} Until the turn of the millennium, the field at Bryant–Denny Stadium had only the necessary markings required for play. As more and more stadiums began to add other designs to the field, such as logos, Alabama chose to remain traditional with the field design. In fact, even into the 2002 season, Bryant–Denny still had no logo at midfield and no logos at the 25-yard lines, which are now commonplace in many stadiums. The end zone design simply consisted of "ALABAMA" in a white, block-style font. During the 2002 season, however, a large white script “A” was added to midfield. The field design underwent full-scale changes beginning with the 2004 season. At midfield, the large white script “A” was replaced with the crimson script “A” logo, encircled by a crimson ring which has "Alabama Crimson Tide" written around it. In addition, the end zone designs were changed to a crimson block-style font outlined in white. For the 2006 season, two identical logos commemorating the 175th anniversary of the university were also added to the field on the 25-yard lines. One was added on the south end of the stadium, on the west side of the playing field, while the other was on the north end of the stadium, on the east side of the playing field. [[File:2011 houndstooth ribbon on the field at Bryant–Denny Stadium.jpg|thumb|right|alt=American football field with a houndstooth awareness ribbon painted on it.|left|Detail of the [[houndstooth]] [[awareness ribbon]] painted on-field in remembrance of the victims and damage of the April 2011 tornado.]] For the 2007 season, two identical logos commemorating the 75th anniversary of the founding of the [[Southeastern Conference]] (SEC) were added to home field of every SEC team. These were in the same places as the 175th logos were during the 2006 season. For the 2008 season, two identical SEC logos were added to the home field of every SEC team. Alabama’s crimson was used as the primary color for the logos at Bryant–Denny. These logos were located in the same places as the previous logos and remain there today. For the 2009 A-day game, the end zones were changed back to the original white block-style font that was used prior to the 2004 season, except that the background was shaded crimson. The north end zone displayed "ALABAMA", while the south end zone displayed "CRIMSON TIDE". This design layout has remained in use since the 2009 season.{{cite web |title=Photo of Bryant-Denny Stadium Design for the 2009 A-day Game|url=http://i40.tinypic.com/dnp09e.jpg|publisher=Tiny Pic}} For the 2011 season, two identical [[houndstooth]] [[awareness ribbon]]s recognizing the ongoing relief efforts following the [[2011 Tuscaloosa–Birmingham tornado|April 27, 2011 tornado]] were added to the field on the 25 yard lines.{{cite web |title=Bryant–Denny Unveils Tornado Ribbons|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/ncaa/football/news?slug=rivals-1259179|work=[[Rivals.com|Rivals]]|date=September 1, 2011|accessdate=September 4, 2011}}{{cite news |title=Alabama's Opener Against Kent State Could Help Healing in Tuscaloosa|first=Izzy|last=Gould|url=http://www.al.com/sports/index.ssf/2011/09/alabamas_opener_against_kent_s.html|newspaper=[[Press-Register]]|location=Mobile|date=September 2, 2011|accessdate=March 25, 2012}} ==Locker rooms== In 2008, the visitors' locker room was officially named "The Fail Room" after alumnus and donor [[James M. Fail]]. He commented, "Earlier this year, when I saw the visitors' locker room as a potential naming right, I figured it was the most appropriate opportunity I would ever have to use my name."{{cite press release |title=Bryant–Denny Stadium Visitors Locker Room Named for James M. Fail|url=http://www.rolltide.com/genrel/121508aab.html|publisher=University of Alabama Department of Intercollegiate Athletics|date=December 15, 2008|accessdate=December 15, 2008}} ==High school championships== Beginning in 2009, Bryant–Denny Stadium and [[Auburn University]]'s [[Jordan–Hare Stadium]] became the homes of the [[Alabama High School Athletic Association]] state football championship games, known as the Super Seven. Bryant-Denny hosts the Super Seven in odd-numbered years, with Jordan–Hare taking the games in even-numbered years. Previously, the Super Six was held at [[Legion Field]] in [[Birmingham, Alabama|Birmingham]]. ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://www.rolltide.com/sports/2016/6/10/facilities-bryant-denny-html.aspx Bryant-Denny Stadium page on Rolltide.com] {{Alabama Crimson Tide football navbox}} {{University of Alabama}} {{Southeastern Conference football venue navbox}} {{Alabama college football venues}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bryant-Denny Stadium}} [[Category:Alabama Crimson Tide football venues]] [[Category:American football venues in Alabama]] [[Category:College football venues]] [[Category:Sports venues in Tuscaloosa, Alabama]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1929]] [[Category:1929 establishments in Alabama]]

revision.comment: ([[c:GR|GR]]) [[c:COM:FR|File renamed]]: [[File:Trade Exhibition Hall 2.jpg]] → [[File:Trade Exhibition Hall, Cairns Convention Centre.jpg]] there are trade exhibition halls all over the place
revision.text:
{{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Cairns Convention Centre | image = Cairns Convention Centre Hero.jpg | nickname = The Snakepit | location = Cnr Wharf & Sheridan Street, [[Cairns]], [[Queensland]], 4870 | coordinates = {{coord|16|55|39|S|145|46|40|E|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = 1995 | opened = June 1996 | owner = [[Government of Queensland]] | operator = [[AEG Ogden]] | surface = various | seating_capacity = 5,300 | tenants = [[Cairns Taipans]] ([[National Basketball League (Australia)|NBL]]) (1999-present)
[[2018 Commonwealth Games]] |}} [[File:Cairns G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors Meeting.jpg|thumb|Cairns G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors Meeting 2014]] [[File:Taipans Hero Image.jpg|thumb|[[National Basketball League (Australasia)|National Basketball League]] team the [[Cairns Taipans]] (in orange) play their home games at the Convention Centre]] [[File:Trade Exhibition Hall, Cairns Convention Centre.jpg|thumb|Trade Exhibition, Hall Two]] [[File:World Buiatrics Congress.jpg|thumb|World Buiatrics Congress 2014]] The '''Cairns Convention Centre''', selected the World’s Best Congress Centre in 2014 and 2004, is a convention and entertainment centre in [[Cairns]], [[Queensland]], [[Australia]].Dalton, Nick. http://www.cairnspost.com.au/news/cairns-convention-centre-takes-out-worlds-best-congress-centre-at-general-assembly-of-the-international-association-of-congress-centres-aipc-in-berlin/story-fnjpvlcp-1226977018615, “Convention Centre World’s Best”, The Cairns Post, July 4, 2014, page 1 ==Description== The centre has a floor space of 31,000 square metres on a 2.2 hectare site in the Cairns CBD, 10 minutes from Cairns International Airport. It has five halls, including the Great Hall, which caters to 2,330 theatre-style guests and can be divided into four separate rooms, and Hall Two, which holds up to 5,300.Cairns Attractions, http://www.cairnsattractions.com.au/explore/grown-up-fun/cairns-convention-exhibition-centre.443.html, “Cairns Convention Exhibition Centre Cairns Australia”, retrieved December 17, 2015. It has nine meeting rooms, six conference rooms, a media room and state-of-the art audio visual facilities.Greenbuild.com.au, http://www.greenbuild.com.au/case-studies/cairns-convention-centre, “Tropical eco building and living”, retrieved December 17, 2015 ==History== The Cairns Convention Centre is owned by the Queensland State Government and has been managed and marketed by [[AEG Ogden]] since 1994. Stage one of the building opened on June 26, 1996 and a multi-purpose 5,300 seat hall was added in 1999.Hudson, Alan (2007).”Growing up with Cairns”, {{ISSN|1322-8587}}, Page 142. It was Australia’s first regional convention centre and the country’s first environmentally designed public building, and in its opening year it won the inaugural international EIBTM’s most environmentally conscious congress centre.Dalton, Nick. http://www.cairnspost.com.au/business/cairns-convention-centre-in-line-for-top-honour/story-fnjpusdv-1226876423326, “Centre turns 15”, The Cairns Post, July 27, 2011 It became home to the Cairns Taipans in 1999, the team’s first year in the NBL. The centre undertook a $12 million refurbishment in 2005 and a $6.3 million upgrade in 2011.Pyne, Rob. http://www.robpyne.com.au/2011/07/13/cairns-convention-centre-6-3-million-upgrade/, “Convention Centre: $6.30 Million Upgrade!”, retrieved December 17, 2015 ==Sport== Since the team's inaugural season in 1999, the Cairns Convention Centre has been the home venue for the [[Cairns Taipans]], who play in the [[National Basketball League (Australasia)|National Basketball League]]. During Taipans home games, the centre is referred to as "The Snakepit".Cairns Taipans, http://www.taipans.com/game-night/venue/, “Venue Cairns Convention Centre”, retrieved December 17, 2015 The Convention Centre is set to host preliminary rounds of the [[Basketball at the Commonwealth Games|men's basketball]] competition at the [[Commonwealth Games]], which will be held on Queensland's [[Gold Coast, Queensland|Gold Coast]] in April [[2018 Commonwealth Games|2018]]. ==Recent events== In 2014, the centre hosted the G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors MeetingForbes, Scott. http://www.cairnspost.com.au/business/top-marks-given-for-g20-finance-ministers-meeting-in-cairns/story-fnjpusdv-1227066093116. “Top marks given for G20 Finance Minister meeting in Cairns”, The Cairns Post, September 22, 2014.Kyriacou, Kate. http://www.couriermail.com.au/news/queensland/brisbane-g20-summit-security-tweaks-after-cairns-finance-ministers-meeting/story-fnihsrf2-1227065836443, “Brisbane G20 summit security tweaks after Cairns finance ministers’ meeting”, The Courier-Mail, September 22, 2014 and the Australian Tourism Exchange conference, the first time it was held in a regional destination.Dalton, Nick, http://www.cairnspost.com.au/business/australian-tourism-exchange-puts-far-north-queensland-on-tourist-menu/story-fnjpusdv-1226908263106, “Australian Tourism Exchange puts Far North Queensland on tourist menu:, The Cairns Post, May 7, 2014Vlasic, Kimberley, Kate. http://www.cairnspost.com.au/business/global-tourism-experts-talk-shop-at-australian-tourism-exchange-in-cairns/story-fnjpusdv-1226915361518, “Australian Tourism Exchange in Cairns”, The Cairns Post, May 13, 2014 Also in 2014, it held the World Buiatrics Congress, the 6th International Symposium on Fish Nutrition and Feeding, the Association of Financial Advisers Conference and Congress of the International Union for the Study of Social Insects.Dalton, Nick. http://www.cairnspost.com.au/news/cairns/cairns-convention-centre-pours-91m-into-the-citys-economy/story-fnjpusyw-1227165640094 “Cairns Convention Centre pours $91m into economy”, The Cairns Post, December 24, 2014 In 2015, it hosted the Professional Bull Riding Cairns Invitational, adding 300 tonnes of sand to the floor of Hall Two, the 25th Meeting of the International Society for Neurochemistry, World Congress on Larynx Cancer, Australasian Hydrographic Symposium, Prostate Cancer World Congress, Toyota Dealer Meeting and Hilux Launch and James Cook University Graduation Ceremonies.Bateman, Daniel. http://www.cairnspost.com.au/lifestyle/scientists-bring-mega-brainpower-to-cairns-for-neurochemistry-conference/story-fnpqqh7k-1227497065493, “Scientists bring mega brainpower to Cairns for Neurochemistry conference”, The Cairns Post, August 25, 2015.Clarke, Harry. http://www.cairnspost.com.au/sport/local-sport/cairns-convention-centre-converted-into-rodeo-arena-for-bull-riding-event/story-fnjpuwsz-1227424199998, “Cairns Convention Centre converted into rodeo arena for bull riding event”, The Cairns Post, July 2, 2015 It has been selected to host the 2018 Commonwealth Games basketball heats.Australian Government, http://statements.qld.gov.au/Statement/2015/11/5/cairns-joins-commonwealth-games-team, “Cairns joins Commonwealth Games team”, November 5, 2015, retrieved December 17, 2015 ==Awards== The Centre received the 2014 and 2004 International Association of Congress Centres (AIPC) APEX Award for World’s Best Congress Centre.Davis, Sam, http://www.abc.net.au/local/stories/2008/07/14/2303143.htm , “Cairns Convention Centre wins award”, ABC Far North Queensland, July 14, 2008 It was inducted into the Queensland Tourism Awards Hall of Fame after winning gold in the 2013, 2014 and 2015 Business Event Venues category and received the Chairman’s Award for Excellence in the Tourism Tropical North Queensland (TTNQ) Industry Excellence Awards.Queensland Industry Tourism Council, http://www.queenslandtourismawards.com.au/results/hall-of-fame, “Hall of Fame 2015, Business Events Venue Cairns Convention Centre”, retrieved December 17, 2015Tourism Tropical North Queensland, http://www.ttnq.org.au/ttnq-awards-excellence-in-tourism/, TTNQ awards excellence in tourism, November 7, 2015, retrieved December 17, 2015 In 2011, it achieved Gold Certification in the AIPC Quality Standards Program.{{cite web|url=http://www.ausleisure.com.au/news/cairns-convention-centre-receives-gold-certification/|publisher=Australian Leisure Management|title=Cairns Convention Centre Receives Gold Certification|date=February 10, 2011}} ==Environment credentials/green initiatives== The centre’s energy efficient features includes rain water storage, water flow restrictors, an insulated roof with light coloured roof sheeting and solar hot water panels and louvers. The centre is ISO 9001 accredited with Lloyd's of London and has an EarthCheck Benchmarked Bronze status. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{Official website|https://www.cairnsconvention.com.au}} {{Cairns Taipans}} {{NBL Arenas|state=collapsed}} [[Category:Convention centres in Australia]] [[Category:National Basketball League (Australia) venues]] [[Category:Music venues in Australia]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in Australia]] [[Category:Cairns Taipans]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Cairns]] [[Category:2018 Commonwealth Games venues]] [[Category:Boxing venues in Australia]] [[Category:Sports venues in Queensland]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Cairns]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1996]] [[Category:Philip Cox buildings]]

revision.text:
{{redirect|Chess master|the Ubisoft application|Chessmaster|the Chinese novel by A Cheng|The Chess Master}} [[Image:Garri kasparow 20070318.jpg|thumb|right|[[Grandmaster (chess)|Grandmaster]] [[Garry Kasparov]]]] A '''chess title''' is a [[title]] created by a [[chess]] governing body and bestowed upon players based on their performance and rank. Such titles are usually granted for life. The most prestigious titles are those granted by the international chess governing body [[FIDE]]; many national chess federations also grant titles such as "National Master".<ref>World Chess Federation. [http://www.fide.com/official/handbook.asp?level=B0101 FIDE Handbook: Chess Rules. 1.0. Requirements for the titles designated in 0.31.] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080315221010/http://www.fide.com/official/handbook.asp?level=B0101 |date=March 15, 2008 }} Retrieved 9 December 2006.</ref>
==Over-the-board chess== In general, a ''chess master'' is a player of such skill that he or she can usually beat most amateurs. Among chess players, the term is often abbreviated to ''master'', the meaning being clear from context.
The establishment of the world chess body, [[Fédération Internationale des Échecs]] (FIDE), saw the creation of titles superior to the "national master" titles. In 1950, FIDE created the titles "[[Grandmaster (chess)|Grandmaster]]" and "[[International Master]]", the requirements for which were increasingly formalized over the years. In 1978 FIDE created the lesser title of "[[FIDE Master]]".
===Early use of the Master title=== From the beginning of recorded chess, to the establishment of the first chess organizations, the term ''master'' was applied informally, being simply a matter of popular acclaim. Strong players demonstrated their strength in play, and gained the informal reputation of being chess masters.
As chess became more widespread in the latter half of the 19th century, the term began to be given out by organizations. One of the most prestigious events of the time was the [[DSB Congress]], first organised by the [[Deutscher Schachbund|Deutscher Schachbund (German Chess Federation)]] in 1876. The DSB's standard for the title of Master was the ''Meisterdrittel'', i.e. to win at least one third of the games in the premiere tournament at a DSB Congress. The winner of the ''Hauptturnier'' or "reserve" event was entitled to compete in the premiere event in the next congress, with a chance to achieve the ''Meisterdrittel''.<ref>{{cite book | last1 = Hooper | first1 = David | last2 = Whyld | first2 = Kenneth | lastauthoramp = yes | year = 1996 | chapter = Hauptturnier | title = The Oxford companion to chess | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=edEZAQAAIAAJ&q=Meisterdrittel&dq=Meisterdrittel&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Shl3Up2KF4yUkwWo9oEY&redir_esc=y | edition = 2 | publisher = [[Oxford University Press]] | publication-date = 1996 | page = 170 | isbn = 978-0-1928-0049-7 | accessdate = 4 November 2013 }}</ref>
===FIDE titles=== {{Main article|FIDE titles}} *''[[Grandmaster (chess)|Grandmaster]]'' (abbreviated as GM, sometimes ''International Grandmaster'' or IGM is used) is awarded to world-class chess masters. Apart from World Champion, Grandmaster is the highest title a chess player can attain. Before FIDE will confer the title on a player, the player must have an Elo chess rating (see below) of at least 2500 at one time and three favorable results (called norms) in tournaments involving other Grandmasters, including some from countries other than the applicant's. There are also other milestones a player can achieve to attain the title, such as winning the World Junior Championship. *''International Master'' (abbreviated as IM). The conditions are similar to GM, but less demanding. The minimum rating for the IM title is 2400. *''FIDE Master'' (abbreviated as FM). The usual way for a player to qualify for the FIDE Master title is by achieving a FIDE Rating of 2300 or more. *''Candidate Master'' (abbreviated as CM). Similar to FM, but with a FIDE Rating of at least 2200. All the titles listed above are open to men and women. Separate women-only titles, such as Woman Grandmaster (WGM), are also available. Beginning with [[Nona Gaprindashvili]] in 1978, many women have also earned the unsegregated GM title.<ref>Current FIDE lists of top players with their titles are online at [http://www.fide.com/ratings/toplist.phtml fide.com] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080430092221/http://www.fide.com/ratings/toplist.phtml |date=April 30, 2008 }}. Retrieved 11 December 2006</ref>
===National titles=== Some [[Chess around the world|national chess federations]] award titles such as "National Master" (NM). National chess federations are free to set whatever standards they want for such titles, which are not recognized by [[FIDE]]. Standards for "Master" titles in different countries vary, but are usually based on criteria such as achieving a certain rating (typically about 2200 [[Elo rating system|Elo]]), achieving the required number of tournament performances ("norms") at a certain level, or featuring prominently in the country's national championship. In some cases, it may extend to honorary titles awarded to (for example) prominent chess administrators, business patrons or politicians. Since the introduction of the [[FIDE Master]] (FM) title in 1978, some federations such as those of Ireland and Germany have ceased awarding National Master titles, apparently regarding them as obsolete.
====Individual federations====
=====Soviet Union===== In the Soviet Union, the Master title was conferred by the federal government and was connected to the title of [[Unified Sports Classification System of the USSR|Master of Sport]]. The first chess player to receive the title was [[Peter Romanovsky]] in 1934. Only players who featured prominently in the [[Soviet Chess Championship]] were considered for the title, and less than 100 awards were made altogether. The majority of these players also qualified for the FIDE [[International Master]] or [[Grandmaster (chess)|Grandmaster]] title.
=====United States===== The [[United States Chess Federation|USCF]] currently gives a national title for achieving 2200 rating (life master): :{| !Title !Rating |- |Life Senior Master |2400 |- |Life Master |2200 |- |Candidate Master |2000 |- |1st Category |1800 |- |2nd Category |1600 |- |3rd Category |1400 |- |4th Category |1200 |} :Note: 1st Category titles and lower do not require the listed rating.
======Expert====== {| class="infobox" |+USCF rating categories |- !Category!!Rating range |- |Senior Master||Over 2400 |- |National Master||Over 2200<ref>Players who maintain a 2200 rating over 300 games are "Life Masters" [http://main.uschess.org/content/view/7327 USCF terms] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130308182917/http://main.uschess.org/content/view/7327 |date=2013-03-08 }}</ref> |- |Expert||2000–2199 |- |Class A||1800–1999 |- |Class B||1600–1799 |- |Class C||1400–1599 |- |Class D||1200–1399 |- |Class E||1000–1199 |- |Class F||800–999 |- |Class G||600–799 |- |Class H||400–599 |- |Class I||200–399 |- |Class J||under 200<ref>The USCF has a rating floor of 100</ref> |}
Chess expert is a title given by the [[United States Chess Federation]] (USCF). It is awarded to [[chess]] players [[Chess rating systems|rated]] from 2000 to 2199. Players rated above that are [[chess master|masters]], while players below that are class players. Approximately 50,000 chess players have USCF ratings, of which approximately 2,500 are rated 2000 or better. Thus, chess experts are in the top 5% of all USCF tournament chess players. Since 2008, USCF has also awarded Candidate Master titles to players that achieve 5 performance-based [[Norm (chess)|'norms']] in tournaments while holding a rating above 2000. Like the title of Master, Candidate Master titles are awarded for life.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.glicko.net/ratings/titles.pdf|title=US Chess Title System, Update Feb 2016|last=|first=|date=Feb 2016|website=|access-date=}}</ref>
The title of chess expert is not awarded for life. Every time a tournament chess player plays a game, his rating goes up or down depending on the game's outcome and on how strong his opponent is. If the rating of a chess expert falls below 2000, he is not a chess expert any more (though he retain the title of Candidate Master, if it was earned according to criteria above). This is in contrast to international titles awarded by [[FIDE]], which are awarded for life. In European countries the term of "expert" is not used. Instead, players of that level are called "[[Candidate Master]]s", although the FIDE Candidate Master title generally requires a higher rating (2200 FIDE).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fide.com/fide/handbook?id=58&view=article|title=Handbook|website=www.fide.com|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130308182527/http://www.fide.com/fide/handbook?id=58&view=article|archivedate=2013-03-08|df=}}</ref>
It is possible (and common), however, for players in the United States to have a rating that places them in the 'expert' category while still retaining the title of 'Life Master' or 'National Master'. The 'title' of 'master' is awarded to anyone meeting the criteria laid down by the USCF, including having once been rated over 2200. Like the FIDE titles of [[FIDE Master]], [[International Master]], and [[Grandmaster (chess)|Grandmaster]], the title of 'Master' is awarded for life. Players with a rating below 2200, but who have earned the title of 'National Master' or 'Life Master', are, according to the USCF, still referred to as 'masters'.
The first USCF rating list was published in December 1950. On that list, experts were players rated from 2100 to 2300 and masters were players rated from 2300 to 2500. However, within a few years, it was discovered that the ratings were rapidly deflating. As a result, the classifications were dropped by 100 points so that since then experts were rated between 2000 and 2200. In 1960, the USCF adopted the new [[Elo rating system]] replacing the original [[Kenneth Harkness|Harkness]] System. There have been continuous adjustments to that system ever since, with the primary purpose of stabilizing the rating system against the forces of inflation and deflation, so that a chess expert today will be approximately the same strength as a chess expert was 20 or 40 years ago.
This information stated here also applies in Canada,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chess.ca/section_7.htm |publisher=CFC |title=701. C.F.C. RATING SYSTEM & FIDE RATED EVENTS |accessdate=2009-12-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090225073722/http://www.chess.ca/section_7.htm |archivedate=February 25, 2009 }}</ref> under the auspices of the Canadian Federation of Chess (CFC), with one difference being that Class E encompasses all players rated under 1200. Similar class distinctions may apply in other national chess federations as well.
======Master====== The [[United States Chess Federation]] (USCF) awards the Title of National Master to anyone who achieves a USCF [[ELO rating system|rating]] of 2200, and the title of Senior Master to anyone who achieves a USCF rating of 2400 along with certain performance-based [[Norm (chess)|'norms']] during tournament play.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.glicko.net/ratings/titles.pdf|title=US Chess Title System Feb 2016|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref> The USCF also awards the Life Master title to anyone who holds a 2200 rating for a total of 300 or more games in his or her lifetime.
In the United States, the title of "National Master" is awarded for life, regardless of whether the rating of a National Master subsequently goes below 2200.<ref>"Meeting Minutes – Board of Directors Meeting – August 2002", United States Chess Federation, PO Box 3967, Crossville, TN 38557</ref> In August 2002, this position was codified (after being recognized as the existing status quo) by the USCF Policy Board with the passage of a motion stating "Any USCF member who has had a regular post tournament rating of 2200 or higher (published or not) has demonstrated a significant level of chess ability and is recognized by being automatically awarded the lifetime title of National Master."
======Life Master====== Life Master is a [[chess]] title awarded by the [[United States Chess Federation]] (USCF). To be awarded this title, one must hold a [[Chess master|master's]] [[ELO rating|rating]] of over 2200 for at least 300 USCF-rated tournament chess games.
During the 1990s, the USCF also awarded a "Life Master" title on the basis of a different and more complex system that was similar to the FIDE 'norm system' of awarding titles. This method of attaining Life Master became officially recognized by the USCF on January 1, 1996. The "class norm" system was later discontinued, and players who had or were subsequently granted the title on the 300-game basis were renamed "Original Life Masters." In practice, the distinction is rarely made. Original Life Masters had to play 300 games as a Master with out going below 2200 in their rating or the count would start over again.
As the name of this title implies, this title is held for life, regardless of any subsequent decrease in rating. Thus it is possible to have a player with a USCF rating of 2100 (or below) who is a Life Master. While this is uncommon for 'Original Life Masters' (since such a rating floor can only be dropped by the USCF itself), Original Life Masters have a floor rating of 2200 .
=====Canada===== The [[Chess Federation of Canada]] awards the title of National Master to players who achieve a national rating of 2200, and three tournament performances ("norms") of 2300 or more. It also awards National Woman Master and National Candidate Master titles.<ref>[http://chess.ca/titleholders CFC Titleholders | The Chess Federation of Canada - La Fédération Canadienne des Échecs] {{webarchive|url=http://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/20131024093658/http://chess.ca/titleholders |date=2013-10-24 }}. Chess.ca. Retrieved on 2013-10-23.</ref>
=====England===== The [[English Chess Federation]] awards the title of National Master to players who achieve an [[ECF grading system|ECF rating]] of 200 or more (equivalent to a FIDE rating of approximately 2250). It also awards a number of lesser titles.<ref>[http://www.englishchess.org.uk/membership/master-points-system/ Master Points System « The English Chess Federation] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131015115154/http://www.englishchess.org.uk/membership/master-points-system/ |date=2013-10-15 }}. Englishchess.org.uk. Retrieved on 2013-10-23.</ref>
=====Ireland===== Up until 1991, the Irish Chess Federation awarded the title of Irish National Master to 15 players. The title has since fallen into disuse.<ref>[http://www.icu.ie/articles/display.php?id=170 Irish National Master] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131021171115/http://www.icu.ie/articles/display.php?id=170 |date=2013-10-21 }}. Icu.ie. Retrieved on 2013-10-23.</ref>
=====Australia===== The title of Australian Master was introduced in 1959, and was awarded by the [[Australian Chess Federation]] using a points based system, in which players were required to score 100 points from performances in major tournaments such as the [[Australian Chess Championship]] and state championships.<ref>{{cite book | author = [[Anne Sunnucks]] | title = The encyclopaedia of chess | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=HJkYAAAAIAAJ&q=%22The+title+of+Australian+Master%22&dq=%22The+title+of+Australian+Master%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=IwlWUvPcKsXNkwWl3IDYCA&redir_esc=y | accessdate = 10 October 2013 | edition = 2nd | year = 1976 | publisher = Robert Hale Ltd | location = London | isbn = 978-0-7091-4697-1 | page = 33 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20131014063038/http://books.google.com/books?id=HJkYAAAAIAAJ&q=%22The+title+of+Australian+Master%22&dq=%22The+title+of+Australian+Master%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=IwlWUvPcKsXNkwWl3IDYCA&redir_esc=y | archivedate = 14 October 2013 | df = }}</ref> According to Australian chess player and arbiter [[Shaun Press]], the requirements were changed to a rating-based system some time during the 1980s, but the title was not held in high regard and is no longer awarded.<ref>[http://chessexpress.blogspot.com/2009/06/australian-master-title.html chessexpress: The Australian Master Title] {{webarchive|url=http://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/20131022194131/http://chessexpress.blogspot.com/2009/06/australian-master-title.html |date=2013-10-22 }}. Chessexpress.blogspot.com (2009-06-07). Retrieved on 2013-10-23.</ref>
=====New Zealand===== The [[New Zealand Chess Federation]] awards the title of National Master using a points based system, based on performances in the [[New Zealand Chess Championship]] and a few other tournaments. 100 points are required for the title of National Master, and 40 points for the title of Candidate Master.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.newzealandchess.co.nz/NZCFdocs/Titles.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-10-21 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029215342/http://www.newzealandchess.co.nz/NZCFdocs/Titles.pdf |archivedate=2013-10-29 |df= }}</ref> As of 31 January 2013, 22 players hold the National Master title, the majority of whom also have FIDE titles.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://newzealandchess.co.nz/NZCFdocs/MP-active%20at%2031-1-13.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-10-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029215302/http://www.newzealandchess.co.nz/NZCFdocs/MP-active%20at%2031-1-13.pdf |archivedate=2013-10-29 |df= }}</ref>
== Chess compositions == <!-- Image with inadequate rationale removed: [[Image:Kasparian.jpg|thumb|Genrikh Gasparyan]] --> {{See also|List of grandmasters for chess composition}} Just as in over-the-board play, in [[chess problem|problem chess]] the titles '''International Grandmaster''', '''International Master''' and '''FIDE Master''' are awarded by FIDE via the [[Permanent Commission of the FIDE for Chess Compositions|PCCC]] (''Permanent Commission for Chess Composition'') for especially distinguished problem and study composers and solvers (unlike over-the-board chess, however, there are no women-only equivalents to these titles in problem chess).
=== Composers === For composition, the title of Grandmaster for chess composition was established in 1959, with [[André Cheron]], [[Arnoldo Ellerman]], [[Alexander Gerbstmann]], [[Jan Hartong]], and [[Cyril Kipping]] being the first honorary recipients. In subsequent years, qualification for the IM title, as well as for the GM title (first awarded in 1972 to [[Genrikh Kasparyan]], [[Lev Loshinsky]], [[Comins Mansfield]], and [[Eeltje Visserman]]) and the FM title (first awarded 1990) has been determined on the basis of the number of problems or studies a composer had selected for publication in the [[FIDE Album]]s. These albums are collections of the best problems and studies composed in a particular three-year period, as selected by FIDE-appointed judges. Each problem published in an album is worth 1 point; each study is worth 1⅔; joint compositions are worth the same divided by the number of composers. For the FIDE Master title, a composer must accumulate 12 points; for the International Master title, 25 points are needed; and for the Grandmaster title, a composer must have 70 points.
=== Solvers === For solvers, the GM (International Solving Grandmaster) and IM titles were both first awarded in 1982; the FM title followed in 1997. GM and IM titles can only be gained by participating in the official [[World Chess Solving Championship]] (WCSC):<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.saunalahti.fi/~stniekat/pccc/wcsc.htm|title=Rules for the WCSC and ECSC|first=Hannu|last=Harkola|website=www.saunalahti.fi|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090719040413/http://www.saunalahti.fi/~stniekat/pccc/wcsc.htm|archivedate=2009-07-19|df=}}</ref> to become a GM, a solver must score at least 90 percent of the winner's points and on each occasion finish in at least tenth place three times within ten successive WCSCs. For the IM title they must score at least 80 percent of the winner's points and each time finish in at least fifteenth place twice within five successive WCSCs; alternatively, winning a single WCSC or scoring as many points as the winner in a single WCSC will earn the IM title. For the FM title, the solver must score at least 75 percent of the winners points and each time finish within the top 40 percent of participants in any two PCCC-approved solving competitions.
=== Judges === The title [[International Judge of Chess Compositions]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.saunalahti.fi/~stniekat/pccc/ij.htm|title=International judges|first=Hannu|last=Harkola|website=www.saunalahti.fi|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071025084555/http://www.saunalahti.fi/~stniekat/pccc/ij.htm|archivedate=2007-10-25|df=}}</ref> is given to individuals considered capable of judging composing tournaments at the highest level.
== Correspondence chess == The [[International Correspondence Chess Federation|International Correspondence Chess Federation (ICCF)]] awards the titles International Master, Senior International Master and [[International Correspondence Chess Grandmaster]]—these are equivalent to similar titles awarded by FIDE for over-the-board chess. The ICCF also runs the World Correspondence Chess Championships. Because these events can last a long time, they may overlap: for instance, in February 2005 [[Joop van Oosterom]] was declared winner of the eighteenth Championship (which began in June 2003), though the winner of the seventeenth Championship (which began in March 2002) had not yet been determined.
==See also== * [[FIDE titles]]
