{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Publix Field at Joker Marchant Stadium | nickname = | image = [[File:Publix Field.PNG]]
[[File:JokerMarchantStadiumLakelandFL.jpg|250px]] | fullname = | location = 2301 Lakeland Hills Boulevard
[[Lakeland, Florida]] 33805 | coordinates = {{coord|28|4|29|N|81|57|3|W|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = September 1965{{cite web |title=Joker Marchant Stadium|first=Graham|last=Knight|url=http://www.baseballpilgrimages.com/spring/lakeland.html|work=Baseball Pilgrimages|date=May 29, 2010|accessdate=September 28, 2011}} | built = | opened = March 12, 1966 | renovated = 2002, 2016, 2017 | expanded = 1988 | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Lakeland, Florida|City of Lakeland]] | operator = [[Detroit Tigers]]
(Stadium Operations)
[[Delaware North]]
(Concessions) | surface = Grass | construction_cost = $360,000
(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|360000|1966}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}}) | architect = Lakeland Engineering Associates | general_contractor= Frank C. Decker Construction Co. | former_names = | tenants = [[Lakeland Flying Tigers]] ([[Florida State League|FSL]]) (1967–2001, 2003–2015, 2017-present)
[[Detroit Tigers]] ([[Major League Baseball|MLB]]) (spring training) (1966–present)
[[GCL Tigers]] ([[Gulf Coast League|GCL]]) | seating_capacity = 8,500 | dimensions = Left - 340ft.
Center - 420ft.
Right - 340ft. }} '''Publix Field at Joker Marchant Stadium''' is a [[baseball]] field in [[Lakeland, Florida]]. The 8,500-seat stadium was opened in 1966 and has had multiple renovations, most recently in 2017. It was named after local resident and former Lakeland Parks and Recreation Director Marcus "Joker" Marchant. It is the [[spring training]] home of the [[Detroit Tigers]] and the regular-season home of the minor league affiliates [[Lakeland Flying Tigers]] and [[Gulf Coast Tigers]]. On March 15, 2011, the largest crowd in the stadium's history (10,307 people) watched a spring training game between the [[Detroit Tigers]] and the [[Boston Red Sox]].{{cite news |title=Spring Attendance Was 2nd All Time for Detroit Tigers|first=Tom|last=Zebold|url=http://www.theledger.com/article/20110418/NEWS/110419393|newspaper=[[The Ledger]]|location=Lakeland|date=April 18, 2011|accessdate=March 5, 2014}} ==Expansions== The stadium could seat 4,900 people when it opened in 1966. In 1988, a bleacher section was added down the left field line, increasing seating capacity to 7,027. In 2002, Joker Marchant Stadium was renovated. The State of Florida's $4.5 million grant was the biggest chunk of the financing, while the Polk County Tourist Development Council chipped in $2 million. The remainder of the renovation's cost was paid for by the Tigers and City of Lakeland, increasing capacity to its present 8,500. In October 2014, the Lakeland City Commission announced part of a new agreement with the Detroit Tigers included the start of a $37 million renovation and upgrade of the 50-year-old stadium, starting in April 2016[http://www.springtrainingonline.com/joker-marchant-stadium-renovations-moving-forward/ Joker Marchant Stadium Renovations on Tap (Spring Training Online)][http://www.theledger.com/article/20141006/news/141009548 The Ledger Newspaper Online] after [[Major League Baseball]] [[Spring Training]]. Funding provided in part by the Detroit Tigers, the City of Lakeland and [[Polk County, Florida|Polk County]]. Two construction firms Barton Malow of [[Southfield, Michigan|Southfield]], [[Michigan]] and Rodda Construction of Lakeland were chosen by the City Commission to oversee the project. The [[Lakeland Flying Tigers]], which are the Detroit Tigers' High Class 'A' Minor League club, played their [[Florida State League]] season at [[Henley Field Ball Park|Henley Field]], 1.5 miles away. ==Naming rights== Under a 20-year deal that ends in 2036, the stadium was renamed Publix Field at Joker Marchant Stadium on the first day of MLB's 2017 Spring Training. The [[Publix]] supermarket chain is headquartered in Lakeland and their hometown field is the only sports complex for which they have purchased naming rights. {{cite web |url=http://www.baynews9.com/content/news/baynews9/sports/article.html/content/news/articles/bn9/2016/8/3/lakeland_s_tigers_st.html |first=Stephanie |last=Claytor |title=Lakeland's Tigers stadium to be renamed, renovated for 2017 |website=Bright House Sports Network |date=August 5, 2016 |accessdate=September 14, 2016}} ==Gallery== File:JokerMarchantLakelandFlorida.jpg|Intersection of Kaline and Horton Way File:JokerMarchantStadium2009.jpg|Detroit Tigers spring training game 2009 File:JokerMarchant behind home plate.jpg| View from behind home plate ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *[http://www.littleballparks.com/Stadium/2002/Lakeland/Lakeland.htm Joker Marchant Stadium Views - ''Ball Parks of the Minor Leagues''] *[http://www.lakelandgov.net/parkrec/JokerMarchantStadium.aspx Lakeland Parks and Recreation Department official site] {{Detroit Tigers}} {{Stadiums of the Grapefruit League}} {{FSL ballparks}} {{GCL Ballparks}} [[Category:Detroit Tigers spring training venues]] [[Category:Sports venues in Lakeland, Florida]] [[Category:Minor league baseball venues]] [[Category:Grapefruit League venues]] [[Category:1966 establishments in Florida]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1966]] [[Category:Gulf Coast League ballparks]]

{{About|the custom and phrase|the 2008 film|Noah's Arc: Jumping the Broom|the 2011 film|Jumping the Broom}} [[File:Catnach broomstick-wedding 1822.jpg|thumb|300px|"Marrying over the Broomstick", 1822 illustration of a "broomstick-wedding" by [[James Catnach]].<ref> "Cathnach's illustrated twopenny-sheets of the 1820s carried charming drawings of broomstick weddings" R. B. Outhwaite, ''Clandestine Marriage in England, 1500-1850'', A&C Black, 1995, [https://books.google.ch/books?id=dmZ14qiH-T0C&pg=PA140#v=onepage&q&f=false p. 140].</ref>]]
'''Jumping the broom''' (or '''jumping the besom''') is a phrase and custom relating to a [[wedding]] ceremony where the couple jumps over a broom. It has been suggested that the custom is based on an 18th-century idiomatic expression for "sham marriage", "marriage of doubtful validity"; it was popularized in the context of the introduction of [[civil marriage]] in Britain with the [[Marriage Act 1836]].
There have also been suggestions that the expression may derive from an actual custom of jumping over a "broomstick" (where "broom" refers to the plant ''[[common broom]]'' rather than the household implement) associated with the [[Romani people]] of the [[United Kingdom]],<ref name="Dundes, Alan page 327">{{cite journal|jstor=541535|title="Jumping the Broom": On the Origin and Meaning of an African American Wedding Custom|first=Alan|last=Dundes|date=26 May 1996|publisher=|journal=The Journal of American Folklore|volume=109|issue=433|pages=324–329|doi=10.2307/541535}}</ref> especially those [[Welsh Kale|in Wales]].<ref name="THOMPSON, T.W. p 21">Thompson, T. W. "British Gipsy Marriage and Divorce Rites", quoted in ''The Times'', Issue 54004, 21 September 1928; p.11. A paper read at the 1928 jubilee congress of the Folk Lore Society in London refers to this: "In Wales there was preserved until recently a marriage ritual of which the central feature was the jumping of the bride and bridegroom over a branch of flowering broom or over a besom made of broom."</ref>
The custom of a marrying couple literally jumping over a broom is now most widespread among [[African Americans]], popularized in the 1970s by the novel and miniseries ''[[Roots: The Saga of an American Family|Roots]]'' but originating in the mid 19th century as a practice in [[antebellum South|antebellum]] [[slavery in the United States]].<ref>Norman Kolpas, Katie Kolpas "Practically Useless Information on Weddings" Thomas Nelson Inc, 2005 p30</ref>
==As an expression for "irregular marriage"== References to "broomstick marriages" emerged in England in the mid-to-late 18th century, always to describe a wedding ceremony of doubtful validity. The earliest use of the phrase is in the 1764 English edition of a French work: the French text, describing an elopement, refers to the runaway couple hastily making ''un mariage sur la croix de l'épée'' (literally ‘marriage on the cross of the sword’), an expression the English translator freely renders as ‘performed the marriage ceremony by leaping over a broomstick’.<ref name="Probert">Probert, R. ''Marriage Law and Practice in the Long Eighteenth Century: A Reassessment'' (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2009)</ref>
A 1774 usage in the ''Westminster Magazine'' also describes an elopement. A man who had taken his under-age bride off to France discovered it was as hard to arrange a legal marriage there as in England, but declined a suggestion that a French [[sexton (office)|sexton]] might simply read the marriage service through before the couple as "He had no inclination for a Broomstick-marriage".<ref>(1774) 2 ''Westminster Magazine'', p. 16</ref> In 1789 the rumoured clandestine marriage between the [[George IV of the United Kingdom|Prince Regent]] and [[Maria Fitzherbert]] is similarly referred to in a [[satire|satirical song]] in ''[[The Times]]'': "Their way to consummation was by hopping o’er a broom, sir".<ref>The Times, Tuesday, 8 September 1789; pg. 4; Issue 1251; col A</ref>
Despite these allusions, research by the [[legal historian]] [[Rebecca Probert|Professor R. Probert]] of [[Warwick University]] has failed to find any proof of an actual contemporary practice of jumping over a broomstick as a sign of informal union. Probert also points out that the word ''broomstick'' was used in the mid-18th century in several contexts to mean ‘something ersatz, or lacking the authority its true equivalent might possess.’ She therefore argues that because the expression ''broomstick marriage'', meaning 'sham marriage', was in circulation, [[false etymology|folk etymology]] led to a belief that people must actually have once signified irregular marriage by jumping over a broom.<ref name="Probert"/> Tyler D. Parry, Associate Professor of African American Studies, contests the claim that no literal jump was used in Britain, arguing that enslaved people of African descent and British migrants engaged in numerous cultural exchanges during the 18th and 19th centuries. He shows numerous correlations between the ceremonies of slaves and those of the rural British, contending it is not simply coincidental that two groups, separated by an ocean, utilized similar matrimonial forms revolving around the broomstick. If British practitioners never used a physical leap, Parry wonders how enslaved people in the US South learned of the custom.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Parry|first1=Tyler D.|title=Married in Slavery Time: Jumping the Broom in Atlantic Perspective|journal=Journal of Southern History|date=May 2015|volume=81|issue=2|pages=273–312|url=https://www.academia.edu/12373198/_Married_in_Slavery_Time_Jumping_the_Broom_in_Atlantic_Perspective_The_Journal_of_Southern_History_Vol._81_No._2_May_2015_pp._273-312}}</ref>
There are later examples of the term ''broomstick marriage'' being used in Britain, always with a similar implication that the ceremony so performed did not create a legally binding union. This meaning survived into the early nineteenth century: during a case heard in London in 1824 regarding the legal validity of a marriage ceremony consisting of nothing more than the groom placing a ring on the bride's finger before witnesses, a court official commented that the ceremony "amounted to nothing more than a broomstick marriage, which the parties had it in their power to dissolve at will."<ref>''The Times'', 13 August 1824, p.3</ref>
A decade later, the [[Marriage Act 1836]], which introduced civil marriage, was contemptuously referred to as the ‘Broomstick Marriage Act’ by those who felt that a marriage outside the [[Church of England|Anglican church]] did not deserve legal recognition.<ref>''Jackson’s Oxford Journal'' 12 September 1840, p. 1; ''Saint Valentine: or, Thoughts on the evil of Love in Mercantile Community: The Galanti Show'' (1843) 13 ''Bentley’s Miscellany'' 151</ref> Some also began to use the phrase to refer to non-marital unions: a man interviewed in Mayhew's ''London Labour and the London Poor'' admitted: "I never had a wife, but I have had two or three broomstick matches, though they never turned out happy."<ref>Volume I, Pg. 389-91. Quoted in Thomas, Donald, ''The Victorian Underworld'' John Murray, 1998. Pg. 62</ref>
[[Tinkers]] were said to have a similar custom of marriage called "jumping the budget", with the bride and groom jumping over a string or other symbolic obstacle.<ref>Chesney, Kellow. ''The Victorian Underworld'' Penguin, 1970. Pg. 92</ref>
[[Charles Dickens]]' novel, ''[[Great Expectations]]'' (first published in serial form in the publication ''[[All the Year Round]]'' from 1 December 1860 to August 1861), contains a reference in chapter 48 to a couple having been married "over the broomstick." The ceremony is not portrayed, but the reference indicates that the readers would have recognized this as referring to an informal, not a legally valid, agreement.<ref>"They both led tramping lives, and this woman in Gerrard-street here, had been married very young, over the broomstick (as we say), to a tramping man,..." DICKENS, C. ''Great Expectations'' (1860-1861), Chap. 48</ref>
It has often been assumed that, in England, jumping over the broom (or sometimes walking over a broom), always indicated an irregular or non-church union (as in the expressions "Married over the [[besom]]", "living over the brush"),<ref>{{cite journal |last=Dundes |first=Alan |authorlink=Alan Dundes |title='Jumping the Broom': On the Origin and Meaning of an African American Wedding Custom |journal=The Journal of American Folklore |volume=109 |issue=433 |date=Summer 1996 |page=327<!--Exact page; article is pp. 324-329--> |doi=10.2307/541535 }}</ref> but there are examples of the phrase being used in the context of legal weddings, both religious and civil.<ref>See Dudley Heath, ‘In Coster-Land’ (1894) 125 ''English Illustrated Magazine'' 517, referring to ‘a newly-made and happy couple on their way from Bethnal Green, where, at the Red Church, they have for the sum of seven-pence halfpenny gone through the ceremony of "jumping the broomstick"’</ref>
Other sources have stepping over a broom as a test of chastity, while putting out a broom was also said to be a sign "that the housewife’s place is vacant" and a way, therefore, of advertising for a wife.<ref>J.G. Whitehead, M. Terry, B. Aitken, ‘Scraps of English Folklore, XII’ (1926) 37 ''Folklore'' 76; Sheila Stewart, ''Lifting the Latch: A Life on the Land'' (Charlbury: Day Books, 2003)</ref>
In America the phrase could be used as slang describing the act of getting married legally, rather than as specifying an informal union not recognised by church or state.<ref>{{cite news|title=In a short story published in 1896 a character remarks of two lovers who are keen to wed, "Young ‘n’ old has be’n lookin’ constant fer these two ter jump the broomstick ‘n’ give ‘em weddin’ cake, ‘n’ chicken pie."|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=29 March 1896}}</ref>
==British Romani customs== In [[Wales]], [[Romani people|Romani]] couples would get married by [[Elopement (marriage)|eloping]], when they would "jump the broom," or over a branch of flowering [[common broom]] or a [[besom]] made of [[Broom (plant)|broom]].<ref name="THOMPSON, T.W. p 21"/> [[Welsh Kale]] and English [[Romanichals]] and Romanichal populations in [[Scotland]] practised the ritual into the 1900s.<ref name="THOMPSON, T.W. p 21" />
According to [[Alan Dundes]] (1996), the custom originated among [[Romani people]] in Wales ([[Welsh Kale]]) and England ([[Romanichal]]).<ref name = "Dundes 327">Dundes, Alan. "'Jumping the Broom': On the Origin and Meaning of an African American Wedding Custom", ''The Journal of American Folklore'', 1996, p.327.</ref>
C.W. Sullivan III (1997) in a reply to Dundes argued that the custom originated among the [[Welsh people]] themselves,<ref>{{cite journal|jstor=541813|title="Jumping the Broom": A Further Consideration of the Origins of an African American Wedding Custom|first=C. W.|last=Sullivan|date=1 January 1997|publisher=|journal=The Journal of American Folklore|volume=110|issue=436|pages=203–204|doi=10.2307/541813}}</ref> known as ''priodas coes ysgub'' ("besom wedding"),<ref name="Gwynn1928">Gwynn, Gwenith (W. Rhys Jones). "'Besom Wedding' in the Ceiriog Valley", ''Folklore'', Vol. 39, No. 2, 30 June 1928, pp.149-166.</ref> Sullivan's source is the Welsh folklorist Gwenith Gwynn (a.k.a. W. Rhys Jones),<ref name="Gwynn1928"/> who assumed that the custom had once existed on the basis of conversations with elderly Welsh people during the 1920s, none of whom had ever seen such a practice. One had claimed that: "It must have disappeared before I was born, and I am seventy-three".<!--we get it. Others had heard of the practice, but all were unclear on the details, their evidence being peppered with phrases such as "it must have" and "I should think".--> Gwynn's dating of the custom to the 18th century rested on the assumption that it must have disappeared before these elderly interviewees were born, and on his misreading of the baptism register of the parish of [[Llansantffraid Glyn Ceiriog]].<ref>Probert, R. (2005) Chinese Whispers and Welsh Weddings, 20 ''Continuity and Change'' 211-228</ref>
Local variations of the custom were developed in different parts of England and Wales. Instead of placing the broom on the ground, and jumping together, the broom was placed in an angle by the doorway. The groom jumped first, followed by the bride.<ref>Jones, T. Gwynn. ''Welsh Folklore'', 1930.</ref> In southwest England, in Wales, and in the border areas between Scotland and England, "[while some] couples ... agreed to marry verbally, without exchanging legal contracts[,] .... [o]thers jumped over broomsticks placed across their thresholds to officialize their union and create new households", indicating that contractless weddings and jumping the broomstick were different kinds of marriage.<ref>Evans, Tanya, ''Women, Marriage and the Family'', in Barker, Hannah, & Elaine Chalus, eds., ''Women's History: Britain, 1700–1850: An Introduction'' (Oxon/London: Routledge, 2005 ({{ISBN|0-415-29177-1}})), p. 60 & n. 19 (n. omitted) (author Evans postdoctoral research fellow, Ctr. for Contemp. Brit. Hist., Institute for Historical Research, London, editor Barker sr. lecturer history, Univ. of Manchester, & editor Chalus sr. lecturer history, Bath Spa Univ. Coll.), citing, at p. 60 n. 19, Gillis, J., ''Married But Not Churched: Plebeian Sexual Relations and Marital Nonconformity in Eighteenth-Century Britain'', in ''Eighteenth-Century Life'', vol. 9 (1985), pp. 32–34, & Leneman, Leah, ''Promises, Promises Marriage Litigation in Scotland, 1698–1830'' (Edinburgh: no publisher, 2003), pp. x–xi.</ref>
==African American custom== [[File:Jumping the Broom2011.jpg|thumb|A 2011 wedding in California]] In some [[African-American]] communities, marrying couples will end their ceremony by jumping over a [[broom]]stick, either together or separately. This practice is well attested for as a marriage ceremony for [[Slavery in the United States|slaves in the Southern United States]] in the 1840s and 1850s who were often not permitted to wed legally. Its revival in 20th century [[African American]] culture is due to the novel and miniseries ''[[Roots: The Saga of an American Family|Roots]]'' (1976, 1977).<ref name="Parry2011"/>
[[Alan Dundes]] (1996) notes the unusual development of how "a custom which slaves were ''forced'' to observe by their white masters has been revived a century later by African Americans as a treasured tradition".<ref name="Dundes 324">Dundes(1996:324-328).</ref>
There have been occasional speculations to the effect that the custom may have origins in [[West Africa]], but there is no direct evidence for this, although Dundes points to a custom of [[Ghana]] where brooms were waved above the heads of newlyweds and their parents.<ref name="Dundes, Alan page 326">Dundes, Alan. "'Jumping the Broom': On the Origin and Meaning of an African American Wedding Custom", ''The Journal of American Folklore'', 1996, p. 326</ref> Among southern Africans, who were largely not a part of the Atlantic slave trade, it represented the wife's commitment or willingness to clean the courtyard of the new home she had joined.<ref name="Dundes, Alan page 326"/> Tyler D. Parry argues the Ghanaian connection is a weak case for its origins, especially considering the ritual used by slaves bears far more similarities to the custom in the British Isles. Parry argues that, despite the racial animus that characterized the US South in the nineteenth century, poor white southerners (many of them descendants of people who used irregular forms of matrimony in Britain) and enslaved people exchanged their cultures between one another at far greater rates than commonly acknowledged.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Parry|first1=Tyler D.|title=The Holy Land of Matrimony: The Complex LEgacy of the Bromstick Wedding in American History|journal=American Studies|date=2016|volume=55|issue=1|pages=81–106|url=https://www.academia.edu/26237514/_The_Holy_Land_of_Matrimony_The_Complex_Legacy_of_the_Broomstick_Wedding_in_American_History_American_Studies_Vol._55_No._1_2016_pp._81-106}}</ref>
Slave-owners were faced with a dilemma regarding committed relationships between slaves. While some family stability might be desirable as helping to keep slaves tractable and pacified, anything approaching a legal marriage was not. Marriage gave a couple rights over each other which conflicted with the slave-owners’ claims.<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=[[The Times]]|date=3 February 1824|page=3|title=The sort of difficulties which might arise were raised by an anti-slavery correspondent in 1824 in ''The Times'' discussing Jamaican slaves. He asked what changes a recent increase in church marriages among them had actually achieved: "Do they legally prevent a master from separating husband and wife, at his pleasure, by sale or transfer? Do they legally bind the husband to the wife, and the wife to the husband? Do they give to the husband the right and the means of redress against the violator of his conjugal peace?"}}</ref> Most marriages between enslaved blacks were not legally recognized during American slavery,<ref>{{cite journal|first=Orville W.|last= Taylor|title= Jumping the Broomstick:Slave Marriage and Morality in Arkansas|journal=The Arkansas Historical Quarterly|year=1958}} Taylor quotes from an 1882 ruling by Justice James Eakin of the Arkansas Supreme Court: 'There were no valid marriages amongst that class [the slaves], in the slave states of America before their general emancipation...'</ref> as in law marriage was held to be a civil contract, and civil contracts required the consent of free persons.<ref>{{cite journal|title= A Slave's Marriage Valid: Its Legality Defined|journal=New York Times|date=20 July 1876}} A New York court upheld the retrospective validity of a marriage between Anthony Jones and Patsy Minor, even though at the time and place it had been contracted such marriages between slaves were not legally recognized. Both Jones and Minor had been slaves in Virginia when, with consent of their respective masters, they declared an intention to live together as man and wife. Jones later died intestate in New York, leaving an estate valued at $15,000; a court ruled in favour of the claims of his widow and surviving son.</ref> In the absence of any legal recognition, the slave community developed its own methods of distinguishing between committed and casual unions.<ref>{{cite journal|title= A Slave's Marriage Valid: Its Legality Defined|journal=New York Times|date=20 July 1876}} 'It appears by the evidence that Anthony Jones and Patsy Minor were named according to the custom among slaves, and that the distinction was recognized among slaves, and by their masters, between such lawful and illicit intercourse, and those who cohabited without such marriage were regarded as disreputable.'</ref> The ceremonial jumping of the broom served as an open declaration of settling down in a marriage relationship. Jumping the broom was always done before witnesses as a public ceremonial announcement that a couple chose to become as close to married as was then allowed.<ref>In 'The Story of My Life' (1897) a white author, [[Mary Ashton Rice Livermore]], described a broomstick wedding she attended at a Virginia plantation c. 1842. The preacher (a fellow slave) encouraged the marrying couple to see the broomstick-jumping as a serious expression of their mutual commitment, although he was well aware of the legal limitations of the ceremony. [http://quod.lib.umich.edu/m/moa/4728109.0001.001/263?page=root;rgn=full+text;size=100;view=image;q1=broomstick]</ref>
Jumping the broom fell out of practice when blacks were free to marry legally.<ref>{{cite book|last=Parry|first=Tyler|title="An Irregular Union: Exploring the Welsh Connection to a Popular African-American Wedding Ritual" in'' Welsh Mythology and Folklore in Popular Culture: Essays on Adaptations in Literature, Film, Television, and Digital Media ''edited by Audrey L. Becker and Kristin Noone|year=2011|publisher=McFarland and Company, Inc.|location=Jefferson, NC|page=123}}</ref> The practice did survive in some communities, and the phrase "jumping the broom" was synonymous with "getting married," even if the couple did not literally jump a broom.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Parry|first1=Tyler D.|title=The Holy Land of Matrimony: The Complex Legacy of the Broomstick Wedding in American History|journal=American Studies|date=2016|volume=55|issue=1|pages=81–106|url=https://www.academia.edu/26237514/_The_Holy_Land_of_Matrimony_The_Complex_Legacy_of_the_Broomstick_Wedding_in_American_History_American_Studies_Vol._55_No._1_2016_pp._81-106}}</ref> However, despite its smaller scale continuity in certain rural areas of the United States (among both black and white communities), it made a resurgence among African Americans after the publication of [[Alex Haley]]'s ''[[Roots: The Saga of an American Family|Roots]]''<ref name="Parry2011">{{cite book|last=Parry|first=Tyler|title="An Irregular Union: Exploring the Welsh Connection to a Popular African American Wedding Ritual"'' in Welsh Mythology and Folklore in Popular Culture: Essays on Adaptations in Literature, Film, Television and Digital Media ''edited by Audrey L. Becker and Kristin Noone|year=2011|publisher=McFarland and Company, Inc.|location=Jefferson, NC|pages=109–110, 123–124}}</ref> Danita Rountree Green describes the African American custom as it stood in the early 1990s in her book ''Broom Jumping: A Celebration of Love'' (1992).
==In popular culture== American singer-songwriter [[Brenda Lee]] released the [[rockabilly]] song "[[Let's Jump the Broomstick]]" on Decca Records in 1959. Via its association with [[Wales]] and the popular [[Besom#In Wicca|association of the broom with witches]], the custom has also been adopted by some [[Wiccans]].<ref>[http://paganwiccan.about.com/od/handfastings/p/BroomJumping.htm Jumping the Broom: Besom Weddings] {{cite book|last=Parry|first=Tyler|title="An Irregular Union: Exploring the Welsh Connection to a Popular African American Wedding Ritual" in'' Welsh Mythology and Folklore in Popular Culture: Essays on Adaptations in Literature, Film, Television and Digital Media ''edited by Audrey L. Becker and Kristin Noone|year=2011|publisher=McFarland and Company, Inc.|location=Jefferson, NC|pages=124–125}} [http://www.bbc.co.uk/northamptonshire/content/articles/2004/08/05/pagan_wedding_feature.shtml Martin Heath, Jumping the broomstick] (bbc.co.uk, 2004). </ref>
A film titled ''[[Jumping the Broom]]'', directed by Salim Akil, and starring [[Paula Patton]] & [[Laz Alonso]] was released on 6 May 2011.
In a 2013 episode of [[Grey's Anatomy]], [[Miranda Bailey]] and Ben Warren jump over a broom at the conclusion of their wedding ceremony.
In the classic 1977 TV mini-series [[Roots (1977 miniseries)|''Roots'']], Kunta Kinte/"Toby" (played by [[John Amos|John Amos as adult Kunta Kinte - Levar Burton played the teenager Kunta Kinte]]) had a marriage ceremony where he and Belle (played by [[Madge Sinclair]]) jumped the broom.
In the 2016 film [[The Birth of a Nation (2016 film)|''The Birth of a Nation'']], a couple getting betrothed is seen jumping a broom.
In an episode of [[The Originals (season 2)]] (Episode 13 "The Devil is Damned") the custom is described as being necessary when a priest is not available and the wedding "couldn't wait."
The custom has been reference twice by rap duo [[Outkast]]: in "Call the Law" on their 2006 album ''[[Idlewild (Outkast album)|Idlewild]]'' and in 2007 song [[International Players Anthem (I Choose You)]].
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== * {{cite book |first=Thony C. |last=Anyiam |title=Jumping the Broom in Style |location= |publisher=Authorhouse |year=2007 |isbn=1-4259-8638-2 }} * {{cite journal |first=Orville W. |last=Taylor |title=‘Jumping the Broomstick’: Slave Marriage and Morality in Arkansas |journal=[[Arkansas Historical Quarterly]] |volume=17 |issue=3 |year=1958 |pages=217–231 |jstor=40018908 }}
==External links== * [https://books.google.com/books?id=HzyEu9BnJ_EC&pg=PA64&dq=broom+jumping&sig=hrb3hDn1fyMgQA9rbajBMGnzFTA Happy is the Bride the Sun Shines on at Googlebooks]

{{Infobox criminal organization | name = Lunada Bay Boys | image = | image_size = | caption = | founded = | founder = | named_after = | founding_location = [[Palos Verdes Estates]] | years_active = 1960s-present | territory = Lunada Bay public beach (and its [[surf break]]s)
as well as its adjacent street
Paseo Del Mar, in [[Palos Verdes Estates]] | ethnicity = [[White Californians|White Californian]] [[surf culture|Localist]]
(Multi-generational Palos Verdes localism) | membership = | leaders = | activities = | allies = | rivals = Redondo Beach surfers, various other regions | notable_members = }} The '''Lunada Bay Boys''' or simply the '''Bay Boys''', are a [[surfer]] [[gang]] in [[Palos Verdes Estates]], [[California]], known for their aggressive [[Surf culture#Localism|localism]]. In 2016, ''[[Newsweek]]'' called the Lunada Bay Boys "America's most notorious surf gang".http://www.newsweek.com/lunada-bay-boys-surfing-gang-480473 The group's territorialism of the Lunada Bay public beach has caused controversy in the legal and surfing worlds. Although the Bay Boys are now often considered a gang, the group had non-violent beginnings in the 1960s as a self-described surfing "family" or [[fraternity]]. ==History== Historically [[Lunada Bay]] had been considered an acclaimed [[big wave surfing|big wave]] winter surf spot, with a [[surf break|right-hand break]].{{cite web |url=https://www.easyreadernews.com/bavada-at-lunada-second-helpings-hamburger-hill-2/ |title=Bravada at Lunada: Second Helpings of Hamburger Hill |newspaper=[[Easy Reader]] |date=February 6, 2014 |accessdate=January 15, 2017 }}{{cite web |last=Mondy |first=Ben |url=http://www.grindtv.com/surf/surfings-5-most-fiercely-protected-local-breaks/ |title=5 of surfing’s most fiercely protected local breaks |publisher=Grind TV |date=May 27, 2016 |accessdate=January 16, 2017 }} The culture of Palos Verdes surfing clubs extends back as far the 1930s with groups such as the Palos Verdes Surfing Club. The Lunada Bay Boys started in the 1960s as a [[fraternity]] of local surfers in the Palos Verdes region. An anonymous member stated, "It was more like a big family. I wouldn’t call it a gang. We used to camp down there every other night. We would almost live down there." The group wasn't known for its localism during the 1960s, and surfers within the group were not as prone to violence. At the time, the Lunada Bay Boys wasn't the only surf crew in the city and neighbored the "[[Portuguese Bend]] crew" (Portuguese Bend Club) as well as the "Haggerty's crew" (Haggerty's Surfing Club) of their respective surf spots.{{cite web |last=Pilolla |first=Ed |url=http://www.dailybreeze.com/social-affairs/20160514/bay-boys-history-times-leadership-change-in-lunada-bay |title=Bay Boys history: Times, leadership change in Lunada Bay |publisher=The Daily Breeze |newspaper=The Daily Breeze |date=May 14, 2016 |accessdate=June 27, 2017 }} Around the time, localism of surf spots was considered common sense due to outside surfers often causing boards to fall in the rocks due to lack of leashes at the time. [[Big wave surfing]] pioneer [[Greg Noll]] as well as U.S. champion Mike Purpus of Redondo Beach would surf with the Bay Boys in Lunada Bay during this era. The acclaim of Lunada Bay as a surf spot led to the creation of Lunada Bay Wetsuits in the late '60s. Mike Purpus and surfers [[Dewey Weber]], Collie Ragland, Don Craig, and [[Donald Takayama]] would model for these Lunada Bay Wetsuits ads. Around this time, members would hang out on a rock ledge, however in the late 60s, a stone balcony was created on the shoreline of Lunada Bay, as a hangout for local surfers (often referred to as their "fort"). In the 1970s a leadership shift happened in which older members moved away, and newer members surfaced into leadership. Older members of the group were stated to have "kept it safe and sane", whereas the newer leadership began to hassle outsiders more directly. A surfer at Lunada Bay expressed that the reason violence escalated in years after was because the younger generation sought to show devotion to the territory in the presence of veteran members.{{cite web |url=http://www.dailybreeze.com/general-news/20161114/accused-lunada-bay-boy-recorded-saying-harassment-is-all-out-of-love |title=Accused Lunada Bay Boy recorded saying harassment is ‘all out of love.’ |publisher=Daily Breeze |date=November 11, 2016 |accessdate=September 16, 2017 }} ==Culture== In the 1960s the Lunada Bay Boys culture was mostly nonviolent and held close alliances with the neighboring Redondo Beach and Hermosa Beach. Activities of the original generation included camping down at the beach, fishing, diving, or shaping their surf boards in their shops. Becoming a member of the group was more relaxed and involved no more than to be a local. One local told ''Stab'' magazine that approximately one quarter to one half of local surfers in Lunada Bay are members of the Lunada Bay Boys.{{cite web |last=Smith |first=Jeb |url=http://stabmag.com/news/so-who-the-hell-are-the-lunada-bay-boys/ |title=So, Who The Hell Are The Lunada Bay Boys? |magazine=Stab |date=2017 |accessdate=September 11, 2017 }} Common acts of localism by the Bay Boys include hassling people, intimidation, vandalizing vehicles, slashing tires, throwing rocks, and inciting violence against non-locals.{{cite web |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1996-12-04/local/me-5657_1_lunada-bay |title=Turf War Between Surfers in Lunada Bay Is Settled |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=December 4, 1996 |accessdate=January 15, 2017 }}{{cite web |last=Carroll |first=Rory |url=https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2015/may/18/california-surf-wars-lunada-bay-localism-surfing |title=California's surf wars: wave 'warlords' go to extreme lengths to defend their turf |publisher=[[The Guardian]] |date=May 18, 2015 |accessdate=January 15, 2017 }} A surfer at Lunada Bay expressed his feelings on localism stating, "If we let every nice guy surf, there’d be a hundred guys out here. You have to nip it in the bud. The reason it’s not crowded is that people protect it. It’s fucked, dude. People think we’re a bunch of assholes, but you know what? We want to keep it like this so we can go somewhere where it’s fucking sacred." ==Legality and lawsuits== The Palos Verdes Estates Police Department has been criticized for not taking effective legal action against the Lunada Bay Boys, with the ''LA Times'' reporting that "city leaders repeatedly downplayed the alleged harassment by the Bay Boys against other surfers at Lunada Bay".{{cite AV media |people=Milena, Diana (Defendant); Ponce, Frank (Palos Verdes Resident) |date=Oct 4, 2016 |title=Both Sides of Lunada Bay Localism Lawsuit Speak Out |medium=Short video |location=Palos Verdes Estates |publisher=The Inertia |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=F0FKWGP2DJM}}{{cite web |last=Therolf |first=Garrett |url=http://www.latimes.com/local/california/la-me-surf-gang-20160509-story.html |title=Surfer gang harassment allegations dismissed by Palos Verdes officials, records sho |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=September 15, 2017 |accessdate=September 15, 2017 }} Palos Verdes Estates Police Chief Jeff Kepley has acknowledged that officers in his department "may have relationships with surfers accused of tormenting outsiders."{{cite web |url=http://www.dailybreeze.com/general-news/20170805/probe-finds-hundreds-could-have-known-about-foiled-bay-boys-sting-operation |title=Probe finds ‘hundreds’ could have known about foiled Bay Boys sting operation |newspaper=Daily Breeze |date=August 5, 2017 |accessdate=September 15, 2017 }} In March 2016, surfer Diana Milena Reed and her lawyer sought an injunction against alleged members of the Lunada Bay Boys, to keep them from surfing at Lunada Bay. This lawsuit included claims of [[sexual harassment]].{{cite AV media |people=Milena, Diana (Defendant); Ponce, Frank (Palos Verdes Resident) |date=Oct 4, 2016 |title=Both Sides of Lunada Bay Localism Lawsuit Speak Out |medium=Short video |location=Palos Verdes Estates |publisher=The Inertia }} The defendants denied Reed's allegations. Defendant Frank Ponce stated the claims were "ridiculous" and that "there are no Bay Boys".{{cite web |last=Ponce |first=Frank|url=http://www.theinertia.com/surf/opinion-lunada-resident-says-lawsuit-is-off-base-bay-boys-not-a-gang/ |title=Opinion: Lunada Resident Says "Lawsuit Is Off-Base; Bay Boys Not a Gang" |publisher=The Inertia |date=April 13, 2016 |accessdate=January 16, 2017 }} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==Further reading== * http://www.newsweek.com/lunada-bay-boys-surfing-gang-480473 * https://www.independent.co.uk/news/they-broke-a-schoolteachers-ribs-and-pelvis-for-daring-to-surf-on-their-turf-1597234.html * https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2015/may/18/california-surf-wars-lunada-bay-localism-surfing [[Category:Street gangs]] [[Category:Surf culture]]

{{EngvarB|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} {{Infobox cricket ground | ground_name = Maharashtra Cricket Association Stadium | nickname = MCA Stadium | image = Sahara Stadium Pune 1.jpg | caption = View of MCA Stadium | country = India | location = [[Pimpri Chinchwad ]], [[Maharashtra]] | establishment = April 2012 | seating_capacity = 37,406{{cite web|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/sports/cricket/india-vs-england-tickets-for-first-odi-sold-out-4448830|title=Pune stadium sold out for India-England ODI}} | owner = [[Maharashtra Cricket Association]] | operator = Pune Stadium Ltd. |architect = [[Hopkins Architects]]{{cite web|url=http://www.hopkins.co.uk/projects/3/135/ |title=MCA Pune International Cricket Centre|publisher=Hopkins |date= |accessdate=3 May 2012}} | tenants = [[Maharashtra cricket team]]
[[Indian Cricket Team]]
[[Pune Warriors India]] (2012–2013)
[[Veer Marathi]] (2013–2016)
[[Kings XI Punjab]] (2015)
[[Rising Pune Supergiant]] (2016–2017)
[[Chennai Super Kings]] (2018-2019) | end1 =Pavilion End | end2 =Hill End | international = true | onlytestdate =23 February | onlytestyear =2017 | onlytesthome =India | onlytestaway =Australia | firstodidate = 13 October | firstodiyear = 2013 | firstodihome = India | firstodiaway = Australia | lastodidate = 27 October | lastodiyear = 2018 | lastodihome = India | lastodiaway = West Indies | firstt20idate = 20 December | firstt20iyear = 2012 | firstt20ihome = India | firstt20iaway = England | lastt20idate = 9 February | lastt20iyear = 2016 | lastt20ihome = India | lastt20iaway = Sri Lanka | date = 27 October | year = 2018 | source = http://www.espncricinfo.com/india/content/ground/545380.html Ground Info }} The '''Maharashtra Cricket Association Stadium''' ({{lang-mr|महाराष्ट्र क्रिकेट असोसिएशन स्टेडियम}}) is a [[cricket stadium]] located at Gahunje, [[Pimpri Chinchwad]], [[Pune]], [[India]]. It serves as the home stadium for the [[Maharashtra cricket team]] including headquarters for the [[Maharashtra Cricket Association]]. With India having the largest cricket audience in the world and Indian influence in international cricket growing, the MCA decided a new stadium was needed. [[Hopkins Architects]] of [[London]] was commissioned to design a new 37,000 seat stadium in Pimpri Chinchwad and the stadium was the result. As of 19 Aug, 2017 it has hosted 1 Test, 3ODIs and 2 T20Is. [[File:Sahara Stadium.jpg|thumb|MCA stadium from outside]] The MCA Stadium was inaugurated in April 2012 by Shri Shantanu Sarnayak of Akola (the former health minister's grandson) and the first match was played between [[Kings XI Punjab]] and [[Pune Warriors]] in April 2012. The first [[Twenty20 International]] match at the stadium was played between [[Indian cricket team|India]] and [[England cricket team|England]] in December 2012. The first [[Test cricket|Test]] match at the venue was played between [[Australian cricket team in India in 2016–17|India and Australia]] in February 2017.{{cite web |url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/india-v-australia-2016-17/content/story/1083824.html |title=Australia brace for tough road test on Pune's debut |accessdate=22 February 2017 |work=ESPN Cricinfo}} ==History== {{see also|List of international cricket centuries on Indian cricket grounds}} The MCA's decision to build a new Cricket stadium in [[Pune]] stemmed from a dispute with the [[Pune Municipal Corporation]]{{cn|date=April 2012}}, regarding ticket allocations for [[Nehru Stadium, Pune|Nehru Stadium]]. This conflict came to a head when an international match between [[India national cricket team|India]] and [[Sri Lanka national cricket team|Sri Lanka]] was moved to [[Kolkata]], with the MCA stating they were in no position to host the match. Following this, the MCA decided a new stadium was needed. MCA Pune was inaugurated by the then [[List of ICC presidents|ICC President]] and [[Minister for Agriculture (India)|Agriculture Minister]] [[Sharad Pawar]] on 1 April 2012.{{cite news|title=International cricket stadium inaugurated near Pune|url=http://www.ndtv.com/article/cities/international-cricket-stadium-inaugurated-near-pune-192642?pfrom=home-cities|accessdate=2 April 2012|newspaper=[[NDTV]]|date=1 April 2012}} In 2013, the Indian company [[Sahara India Pariwar]] bought the naming rights and the stadium was renamed the Subrata Roy Sahara Stadium. However, the name was changed back to the Maharashtra Cricket Association Stadium because Sahara paid only a part of the Rs. 200 crore that it had promised when acquiring the rights.[http://www.indianexpress.com/news/naming-rights-tussle-sahara-stadium-to-go-by--mca--name/1167970/ Naming rights tussle: Sahara stadium to go by ‘MCA’ name]. Indian Express (2013-09-12). Retrieved on 2013-12-23. In November 2015, the stadium was selected as one of the six new Test venues along with [[Holkar Stadium]], [[JSCA International Stadium Complex]], [[Saurashtra Cricket Association Stadium]], [[Himachal Pradesh Cricket Association Stadium]] and [[Dr. Y.S. Rajasekhara Reddy ACA-VDCA Cricket Stadium]] in India.{{cite web|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/india/content/story/938911.html|title=BCCI revamps selection committee, announces new Test centres|work=espncricinfo.com}} ===Construction=== The stadium was designed by British architecture company, [[Hopkins Architects]]. Its original completion date was November 2010 at a cost of Rs 1.50 billion, covering and area of {{convert|35|acre|m2}}.{{cite web|url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/pune-to-have-own-cricket-stadium/230931/ |title=Pune to have own cricket stadium |publisher=Indian Express |date=22 October 2010 |accessdate=3 May 2012}} However, the stadium was ready by 2012. As a result, the stadium was not able to host [[ICC Cricket World Cup]] matches as originally intended. The site is located close to the [[Mumbai Pune Expressway]], just outside the city of [[Pune]], with dramatic views of the surrounding mountains. The stadium and the seating arrangement have been designed in such a way that an unobstructed view is assured from each location. The most important feature of this stadium is the rainwater drainage system. Often, matches are abandoned due to heavy downpour. To overcome this problem, MCA opted for sand-based outfield developed departmentally with technical assistance from STRI Limited, UK. Due to this technology, even during heavy showers, water on the outfield drained out fast making it ready for play again just in few minutes. ===Notable Events=== In 2018 IPL, due to members of a few fringe political parties staging protests outside the [[M. A. Chidambaram Stadium]], [[Chennai]] as well as several parts of Chennai demanding the IPL matches to be moved out of the city until the Cauvery Management Board (CMB) was set up as directed by the honourable Supreme Court of India. Despite tight security for the match against KKR, the Chennai police expressed their inability in ensuring enough personnel at the venue for the smooth conduct of the remaining games. MCA Stadium in Pune was selected to host remaining six home games of [[Chennai Super Kings]] [[File:Sahara Stadium Pune 4.jpg|thumb|right|[[Subrata Roy Sahara Stadium]] at Gahunje, the home ground of Pune Warriors India from 2012–2013]] == Controversy == In October 2017 a stadium groundsman, Pandurang Salgaoncar, was sacked after video emerged of him allegedly agreeing to tamper with the [[wicket]] before a one-day international between [[New Zealand cricket team in India in 2017–18|India and New Zealand]]. The sting operation was conducted by [[India Today (TV channel)|India Today TV]]. They captured Salgaoncar on camera allegedly stating he would prepare the pitch to suit two unnamed bowlers. The second ODI went ahead on schedule after the pitch had been inspected by match referee Chris Broad. The India Today footage of Salgaoncar speaking with a reporter, who was posing as a [[Bookmaker (gambling)|bookmaker]], was broadcast a few hours before the match.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/cricket/41753622|title=India v New Zealand: Groundsman sacked after TV sting tampering claims|last=|first=|date=|website=BBC News|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=25 October 2017}} ==Feature== The MPIC project included: * A main 15 wicket match ground * Adjacent practice ground with nets, for practice and smaller matches * Spectator seating for 37,406 grouped into 4 stands * A Members' Pavilion and a media stand * Additional facilities for 5,000 members including [[squash (sport)|squash]] and badminton courts, a [[human swimming|swimming pool]], [[spa]], restaurants and bars * 80 corporate hospitality boxes * A state-of-the-art indoor Cricket Academy with residential accommodation for youth training schemes * Parking for almost 4,000 cars and 10,000 two-wheelers.{{cite web|title=MCA|url=http://www.constructionupdate.com/News.aspx?nId=xkE33MUk2uTSfxRQM5ec0Q==|accessdate=27 February 2013}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://www.hopkins.co.uk/projects/3/135/ hopkins] * [http://www.internationalsportsturf.com internationalsportsturf] {{Pune topics}} {{List of cricket grounds in India}} {{Indian Premier League}} {{Coord|18|40|28|N|73|42|23|E|display=title|type:landmark}} [[Category:Buildings by Hopkins Architects]] [[Category:Cricket grounds in Maharashtra]] [[Category:Sports venues in Pune]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2012]] [[Category:Cricket grounds in Pune]] [[Category:Sport in Pimpri-Chinchwad]] [[Category:Test cricket grounds in India]]

revision.text:
The '''Nevada Boxing Hall of Fame''' (abbreviated '''NVBHOF''') is a [[non-profit]] [[501(c)(3) organization]] founded in June 2012 by American sports broadcaster [[Rich Marotta]].<ref>[http://espn.go.com/blog/dan-rafael/post/_/id/2675/nevada-gets-own-hall-of-fame Nevada gets own hall of fame] ESPN.com</ref> The company honors boxers and those in the industry who have significantly contributed to the state of [[Nevada]], and donates proceeds toward Nevada-based/boxing-related charities and causes.
In December 2012, an inaugural class of 19 inductees was announced at a press conference in [[North Las Vegas]] at former professional boxing referee [[Richard Steele (referee)|Richard Steele]]'s boxing gym. Amongst the inductees were boxers [[Mike Tyson]], [[Julio Cesar Chavez]], [[Larry Holmes]], [[Oscar De La Hoya]], [[Sugar Ray Leonard]], trainers [[Eddie Futch]] and [[Freddie Roach (boxing)|Freddie Roach]], referees [[Mills Lane]] and [[Joe Cortez]], as well promoters [[Bob Arum]] and [[Don King (boxing promoter)|Don King]].<ref>[http://www.lasvegassun.com/news/2012/dec/19/mike-tyson-sugar-ray-leonard-among-first-inductees/ Mike Tyson, Sugar Ray Leonard among first inductees in Nevada Boxing Hall of Fame] Las Vegas Sun</ref>
The organization hosted its first annual induction ceremony in August 2013 in [[Las Vegas Valley|Las Vegas]], Nevada.<ref>[http://www.nvbhof.com/events Nevada Boxing Hall of Fame Events] NVBHOF.com</ref>
In 2016 [[Christy Martin (boxer)|Christy Martin]] became the first female boxer inducted into the Nevada Boxing Hall of Fame.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thenewstribune.com/sports/article64804002.html|title=Nevada Boxing Hall of Fame to induct 11, including 1st woman|work=thenewstribune|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160309080420/http://www.thenewstribune.com/sports/article64804002.html|archivedate=2016-03-09|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://boxingjunkie.usatoday.com/2016/03/08/first-female-voted-into-nevada-boxing-hall-of-fame/|title=First female voted into Nevada Boxing Hall of Fame|work=Boxingjunkie}}</ref><ref>[http://www.orlandosentinel.com/sports/os-christy-martin-george-diaz-0805-20160804-column.html Christy Martin finally stands alone as boxing Hall of Famer - Orlando Sentinel<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *{{Official website|http://www.nvbhof.com}} *{{facebook|nvbhof|Nevada Boxing Hall of Fame}} *{{Twitter}}

{{EngvarB|date=March 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2014}} {{Infobox Stadium | stadium_name = Nyayo National Stadium | nickname = | image = [[Image:Nyayo stadium.jpg|260px]] Aerial view: [[Image:Nyayo stadium from above.jpg|260px]] | fullname = | location = [[Nairobi]], Kenya | coordinates = {{Coord|1|18|13|S|36|49|27|E|display=inline}} | broke_ground = | built = | opened = 1983 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Sports Stadia Management Board]] | operator = [[Sports Stadia Management Board]] | surface = Grass | construction_cost = | architect = Nyanja Architects and Associates | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = | tenants = [[AFC Leopards]]
[[Gor Mahia FC]]
[[African Championships in Athletics]] | seating_capacity = 30,000 | dimensions = | scoreboard = }} '''Nyayo National Stadium''' is a [[multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Nairobi]], Kenya. It is located near the city centre. The stadium was built in 1983 for a capacity of 30,000. It is currently used mostly for [[association football|football]] matches. The popular [[AFC Leopards]] football club plays most of its home games at Nyayo stadium. The stadium is also used for [[Athletics (track and field)|athletics]] and various ceremonies. Other facilities at the Nyayo Stadium include a gymnasium and a 50-metre swimming pool. Rugby union club [[Mwamba RFC]] used the Nyayo National Stadium for home games. The completion of the Nyayo Stadium gave Kenya the opportunity to be placed in the category of nations that were invited to bid for the [[1987 All-Africa Games|4th All-Africa Games]] in 1987, a bid that was awarded to Kenya, giving it International status. In essence, the Nyayo Stadium "gave birth" to [[Moi International Sports Centre]]. The Nyayo Stadium was the host venue of the [[2010 African Championships in Athletics]]. The stadium was renamed to the '''[[Coca-Cola]] National Stadium'''{{cite web |title=Nyayo National Stadium renamed in $1.5M |publisher=variouse |url=http://www.kenyafootball.com/index.php?doc=story&id=3426&categ=1&PHPSESSID=881b3f89f8675c3afa5aac040f1a08bd |accessdate=4 February 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713144449/http://www.kenyafootball.com/index.php?doc=story&id=3426&categ=1&PHPSESSID=881b3f89f8675c3afa5aac040f1a08bd |archivedate=13 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }} after the multi-national company won the naming rights to the stadium in February 2009. The deal was worth USD 1.5 million and would have seen the beverage company do branding, marketing and naming to the whole stadium for three years. Three months later, however, Coca Cola withdrew from the contract, because the Kenyan government wanted to have the stadium branded as Coca Cola Nyayo National Stadium.{{cite web |title=Nyayo Stadium no longer on the Coke side of life |publisher=Daily Nation |url=http://www.nation.co.ke/sports/football/-/1102/601640/-/10enrmm/-/ |accessdate=26 May 2009 }} but was renamed again to the Nyayo National Stadium, as the [[Government of Kenya]] wanted it branded. This decision has been widely criticised by many Kenyan citizens, because they believe that Coca-Cola would have heavily improved and popularised the stadium. The stadium houses headquarters for the [[Football Kenya Federation]] and [[Athletics Kenya]]. ==Components== ===Main stadium=== The main stadium, holding 30,000 people and a FIFA-approved [[Football pitch|standard-size football pitch]], also contains [[floodlights]], 2 [[VIP lounges]], a [[boardroom]] and an internet-enabled [[International Broadcast Centre|media centre]]. The stadium can also be and has also been used to host concerts, public holiday celebrations, public rallies, meetings and [[crusade]]s. ===Aquatic Centre=== The aquatic centre holds 2,000 people and contains a [[filtration plant]] and a public 50 x 25 m swimming pool. ===Indoor Gymnasium=== The indoor gymnasium holds 2,500 people and is the home of the Kenya National Basketball League and the [[Kenya national basketball team]]. It also features [[Floodlights (sport)|floodlights]], electronic [[scoreboards]], [[snack bar]]s, a [[boxing ring]], an indoor [[badminton]] court, a martial arts gym and other social facilities. ===Handball and volleyball training courts=== The handball and volleyball courts can accommodate up to 1,500 spectators and feature outdoor training courts. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.stadiumskenya.co.ke Sports Stadia Management Board] – A body governing few stadiums in Kenya, including the [[Moi International Sports Centre]] *[http://www.worldstadiums.com/stadium_pictures/africa/kenya/nairobi_nyayo.shtml Photo] at [http://www.worldstadiums.com/ WorldStadiums.com] *[http://www.fussballtempel.net/caf/KEN/Nyayo.html Photos] at [http://www.fussballtempel.net/ FussballTempel.net] *[http://www.nairobikenya.com/entertainment/sports/nyayo-national-stadium/ Videos] at [http://www.nairobikenya.com/ NairobiKenya.com] {{Sports venues in Kenya}} {{coord|1|18|15.1|S|36|49|28.1|E|type:landmark|display=title}} [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1983]] [[Category:Football venues in Kenya]] [[Category:Sports venues in Kenya]] [[Category:Sport in Nairobi]] [[Category:National stadiums|Kenya]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in Kenya]] [[Category:1980s in Nairobi]]

{{Infobox football club | clubname = OMR El-Annasser | image = [[Image:OMR El Annasser.png|100px|Logo]] | fullname = Olympic Mostakbel Ruisseau
El Annasser | nickname = Ruisseau | founded = 1962 | ground = [[Stade 20 Août 1955]]
[[Mohamed Belouizdad]], [[Algeria]] | capacity = 10,000 | chairman = | manager = | league = [[Inter-Régions Division]] | season = [[2017–18 Inter-Régions Division|2017–18]] | position = | current = 2018–19 OMR El Annasser season | pattern_la1 =_blackshoulders | pattern_b1 = _whitestripes | pattern_ra1 =_blackshoulders | leftarm1 = FFFFFF | body1 = 000000 | rightarm1 = FFFFFF | shorts1 = 000000 | socks1 = 000000 | pattern_la2 = | pattern_b2 = _thinblacksides | pattern_ra2 = | pattern_sh2 = FFFFFF | pattern_so2 = | leftarm2 = FFFFFF | body2 = FFFFFF | rightarm2 = FFFFFF | shorts2 = FFFFFF | socks2 = FFFFFF }} '''Olympic Mostakbel Ruisseau El Annasser''' ({{lang-ar|أولمبي مستقبل العناصر}}), known as '''OMR El Annasser''' or simply '''OMR''' for short, is an [[Algeria]]n [[football (soccer)|football]] club based in the [[Mohamed Belouizdad]] quarter of [[Algiers]]. The club was founded on 1962 and its colours are black and white. Their home stadium, [[Stade 20 Août 1955]], has a capacity of 10,000 spectators. The club is currently playing in the [[Inter-Régions Division]]. ==History== It was founded in 1962, the year of the [[Algerian War of Independence|Algerian Independence]]. The club played one season in the [[Algerian Ligue Professionnelle 1]] before being relegated to the [[Algerian Championnat National 2]] one year later.{{Cite web|url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablesa/alg08.html|title=Algeria 2007/08|website=www.rsssf.com|access-date=2017-09-15}} The team was relegated to the [[Championnat National de Football Amateur]] after the 2008/2009 season.[http://www.rsssf.com/tablesa/alg09.html Algeria 2008/09] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304043759/http://www.rsssf.com/tablesa/alg09.html |date=March 4, 2016 }} ===Stadium=== The team played its home matches in [[Stade 20 Août 1955]], which seats 15,000. ==Honours== * '''[[Algerian Championnat National 2]] (01)''' ** Champion : 2006 ==Current squad== ==Sponsors== ==Notes== {{reflist}} {{Algerian Ligue Professionnelle 1}} {{DEFAULTSORT:El Annasser, OMR}} [[Category:Football clubs in Algeria]] [[Category:Association football clubs established in 1962]] [[Category:Football clubs in Algiers]] [[Category:1962 establishments in Algeria]] [[Category:Sports clubs in Algeria]] {{Algeria-footyclub-stub}}

Yesika Jimenez was the delegation's [[2008 Summer Olympics national flag bearers|flagbearer]] at the [[Olympic Games#Opening|Opening Ceremony]].{{cite web|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2008-08/08/content_9054194.htm|title=Flag-bearers for Beijing Olympic Games opening ceremony_English_Xinhua|accessdate=2008-08-24}} Panama's participation was initially uncertain. The country was suspended by the [[International Olympic Committee]] in July 2007, due to what was described as government interference in Panama's [[National Olympic Committee]]. {{Multiple issues|{{orphan|date=January 2014}}{{BLP sources|date=January 2014}}{{no footnotes|date=January 2014}}}} [[File:Rabii bhouri.jpg|thumb|rabii bhouri..sport mag]] [[File:Rabii Bhouri lors de la super coupe de Tunisie de basketball.jpg|thumb|rabii bhouri.. commenting on the matches of the Tunisian championship]] [[File:Rabii bhouri avec Salah mejri le pivot de Dallas mavericks en NBA.jpg|thumb|rabii bhouri with nba player salah mejri]] '''Rabii Bhouri ربيع البحوري''' ({{lang-ar|ربيع البحوري}}) is a [[Tunisian people|Tunisian]] sports [[journalist]] officiating at the Tunisian National Television. He is basketball commentator, reporter, producer and presenter. He graduated from the [[Institute of Press and Information Sciences of Tunis]] in 2001.
As a producer-presenter Rabii Bhouri produced and presented many sport's program as "sunday sport","sport mag","foot ball show","daily summaries of the African Cup of Nations", he also presented the sports section in the newscast 20h.
Rabii Bhouri commented various events Basketball such as the 2012 Olympic games, the championship of Tunisia from 2003 to 2018, Arab nations championships 2008, 2009 and 2016 the African Champions League in 2013,2014 and 2017 (he got the award for Best Media Coverage in Championship African club champions in 2014), the Afro Basketball 2009,2015 and 2017, Arab Championship 2008 champions clubs, the 2013 Mediterranean games, Maghreb Championship Champion Clubs 2012, etc. Rabii Bhouri also was a reporter on the show "Sunday Sport" from 1999 to 2010.
Rabii Bhouri provided coverage of the Paralympic Summer Games 2008 in Beijing, the final of the Champion's league football in Africa in Abuja, Nigeria in 2004, the world championship of handball in Germany in 2007, the Arab Club Championship in Basketball in Egypt in 2009, Handball Africa cup of nations in Egypt 2016 etc....
==References== <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.alhasri.com/%D8%AC%D8%AF%D9%8A%D8%AF-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%AA%D9%84%D9%81%D8%B2%D8%A9-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%88%D8%B7%D9%86%D9%8A%D8%A9-%D8%A8%D8%B1%D9%86%D8%A7%D9%85%D8%AC%D8%A7%D9%86-%D8%B1%D9%8A%D8%A7%D8%B6%D9%8A%D8%A7%D9%86-%D9%85%D9%86-%D8%AA%D9%82%D8%AF%D9%8A%D9%85-%D8%B9%D8%A7%D8%A6%D8%AF%D8%A9-%D8%B9%D8%B1%D8%A8-%D9%88%D8%B1%D8%A8%D9%8A%D8%B9-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%A8%D8%AD%D9%88%D8%B1%D9%8A|title=جديد التلفزة الوطنية : برنامجان رياضيان من تقديم عائدة عرب وربيع البحوري|website=www.alhasri.com|language=ar|access-date=2018-02-11}}</ref>

{{Malay name|Said|Abdullah}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Said Abdullah | fullname = Mohammad Sadiy bin Abdullah Tujoh | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1966|09|20|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Brunei]] | height = | position = [[Midfielder#Attacking midfielder|Attacking midfielder]], [[Forward (association football)|Forward]] | currentclub = Retired | clubnumber = | youthyears1 = | youthclubs1 = | years1 = 1993–1999 | caps1 = | goals1 = | clubs1 = [[Brunei (Liga Premier team)|Brunei]] | nationalyears1= 1993–2001 | nationalcaps1= 13+ | nationalgoals1= 5+ | nationalteam1= [[Brunei national football team|Brunei]] | club-update = 17 April 2017 | ntupdate = 17 April 2017 }}
'''Mohammad Sadiy bin Abdullah Tujoh''' (born 20 September 1966), more famously known as '''Said Abdullah''' is a [[Brunei]]an former [[Association football|footballer]] who played as a [[Forward (association football)|second striker]] or in an [[Midfielder#Attacking midfielder|advanced midfield role]].<ref>{{cite web |title=S. Abdullah Tujoh|url=https://int.soccerway.com/players/mohammad-said-bin-abdullah-tujoh/296510/|date=|publisher=Soccerway|accessdate=17 May 2017}}</ref> One of the stars of [[Football in Brunei|Bruneian football]] in the mid-nineties playing for the [[Brunei (Liga Premier team)|Brunei national representative team]] in the [[Malaysian League|Malaysian league]], he was a member of the 1999 [[Malaysia Cup]] winning side, deemed as Brunei's greatest footballing feat.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ww1.utusan.com.my/utusan/info.asp?y=1999&dt=1207&pub=utusan_malaysia&sec=Sukan&pg=sp_03.htm|title=Barisan muda Brunei tahun depan|publisher=''[[Utusan Malaysia]]''|date=7 December 1999|accessdate=17 May 2017}}</ref>
Although his given name is '''Sadiy''', it is often mistaken for '''Saidy''' or more frequently '''[[Said]]''', which would become his default name in publications during his playing years.
==National career==
Said began playing for the Wasps in 1993 under English coach [[Mick Lyons (English footballer)|Mick Lyons]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=7DpOAAAAIBAJ&sjid=9RMEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4199%2C1508772|title=Marlon sparks Police win|via=Google News Archive Search|date=14 August 1993|publisher=New Straits Times|accessdate=17 May 2017}}</ref> Perennial minnows at first (Brunei finished in last place in the inaugural [[Liga Perdana (1994–97)|1994 Liga Perdana]]), Brunei improved on their league finish towards the end of the century, finishing an all-time high of third place in [[1998 Liga Perdana 1|1998]].
Said was part of the Brunei squad in 1999 to win the [[Malaysia Cup]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mleague.netfirms.com/archive/1999/msia/bru.html|title=Brunei 1999|publisher=M-League Online|date=|deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080820210938/http://www.mleague.netfirms.com/archive/1999/msia/bru.html|archivedate=20 August 2008|accessdate=17 May 2017}}</ref> It was to be his final year with the M-League team as he immediately retired from the team along with six other players.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1309&dat=19991206&id=a_1OAAAAIBAJ&sjid=fRQEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5126,4233406&hl=en|title=Breaking up is hard to do|via=Google News Archive Search|date=6 December 1999|publisher=New Straits Times|accessdate=17 May 2017}}</ref>
==International career== Said regularly played for the [[Brunei national football team]] at the [[Southeast Asian Games]] of the nineties, scoring five (known) goals. He scored twice in two defeats at the group stage of the [[Football at the 1993 Southeast Asian Games|17th SEA Games]] held in [[Singapore]] in 1993, against [[Laos national football team|Laos]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=XOoVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=CRQEAAAAIBAJ&pg=3983%2C3124216|title=Laos shock Brunei|via=Google News Archive Search|date=8 June 1993|publisher=New Straits Times|accessdate=17 May 2017}}</ref> and [[Malaysia national football team|Malaysia]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=XuoVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=CRQEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6002%2C3780279|title=A winning start|via=Google News Archive Search|date=10 June 1993|publisher=New Straits Times|accessdate=17 May 2017}}</ref> Five years later in [[Indonesia]], Said scored Brunei's solitary goal of the [[Football at the 1997 Southeast Asian Games|19th SEA Games]] against [[Myanmar national football team|Myanmar]] in a 1-6 defeat.<ref>{{cite web |title=South East Asian Games 1997 (Jakarta, Indonesia)|url=http://www.rsssf.com/tabless/sea97.html|date=17 September 2001|publisher=Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation|accessdate=17 May 2017}}</ref>
When [[Brunei]] hosted the SEA Games in [[1999 Southeast Asian Games|1999]], Said scored twice in Brunei's opening group stage match against [[Cambodia national football team|Cambodia]] in a 3-3 draw. The point gained at the [[Berakas Sports Complex]] would ultimately be Brunei's only one for the tournament.<ref>{{cite web |title=South East Asian Games 1999 Details (Bandar Seri Begawan, Brunei)|url=http://www.rsssf.com/tabless/sea99-det.html|date=26 April 2002|publisher=Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation|accessdate=17 May 2017}}</ref>
Sadiy was a surprise inclusion for Brunei's [[2002 FIFA World Cup qualification|2002 World Cup qualifying]] campaign in early 2001, two years after his retirement from the national team.<ref>{{cite web |title=Football - Brunei soccer teams unveiled|url=http://www.e-borneo.com/cgi-bin/np/viewnews.cgi?category=2&id=986357099|date=4 April 2001|publisher=Borneo Bulletin|accessdate=17 May 2017}}</ref> He played in all six games where Brunei remained winless and goalless, suffering a record 0-12 loss at the hands of the [[United Arab Emirates national football team|United Arab Emirates]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Football - UAE show no mercy |url=http://www.e-borneo.com/cgi-bin/np/viewnews.cgi?category=2&id=987307511|date=15 April 2001|publisher=Borneo Bulletin|accessdate=17 May 2017}}</ref> Brunei would not play another World Cup qualifier until 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bt.com.bn:80/art-culture/2010/02/01/saga-bruneis-football-association|title=Saga of Bruneis football association|publisher=The Brunei Times|date=1 February 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160622003623/http://www.bt.com.bn/art-culture/2010/02/01/saga-bruneis-football-association|archivedate=22 June 2016|accessdate=17 May 2017|df=}}</ref>
==Honours== ;Brunei M-League team *[[Malaysia Cup]]: 1999
==Personal life== Sadiy is a [[firefighter]] off the pitch,<ref>{{cite web |title=Anggota Bomba dan Penyelamat dinaikkan pangkat|url=http://www.pelitabrunei.gov.bn/Arkib%20Dokumen/2010/April/PB280410.pdf|date=28 April 2010|publisher=Pelita Brunei|accessdate=17 May 2017}}</ref> with the rank of Deputy Station Officer of [[Liang, Belait|Sungai Liang]] Fire Station.<ref>{{cite web |title=Warga Balai Bomba Sg Liang berhari raya|url=http://mediapermata.com.bn/warga-balai-bomba-sg-liang-berhari-raya/|date=11 August 2015|publisher=Media Permata|accessdate=17 May 2017}}</ref> He is currently active in veteran football, winning three VFA Sumbangsih Cups with [[Al-Idrus FC]] Veterans.<ref>{{cite web |title=Al-Idrus julang Piala Sumbangsih|url=http://mediapermata.com.bn/al-idrus-julang-piala-sumbangsih/|date=20 February 2017|publisher=Media Permata|accessdate=17 May 2017}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
==External links== *{{Soccerway|mohammad-said-bin-abdullah-tujoh/296510}}

{{infobox stadium |stadium_name=Shenyang Olympic Sports Centre Stadium
沈阳奥林匹克体育中心 | nickname = Crystal Crown |image=[[File:Олимпийский стадион Шэньян2.JPG|250px|Shenyang Olympic Sports Center Stadium (inside)]] |location=[[Shenyang]], [[People's Republic of China|China]] |opened=2007 |owner= |coordinates = {{coord|41.739037|123.457484|type:landmark|display=inline}} |architect= AXS Satow | construction_cost = |tenants= [[Liaoning Whowin]] |seating_capacity=60,000 }} The '''Shenyang Olympic Sports Center Stadium''' ({{zh|s=沈阳奥林匹克体育中心|t=瀋陽奧林匹克體育中心|p=Shěnyáng Àolínpǐkè Tǐyù Zhōngxīn}}) is a 60,000-seat [[multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Shenyang]], [[People's Republic of China|China]]. Nicknamed "[[Crystal]] [[Crown (headgear)|Crown]]" 水晶皇冠, the stadium was built by AXS Satow{{cite web |url=http://www.axscom.co.jp/portfolio/world/03011/index.php |title=瀋陽オリンピック体育センター・スタジアム |trans-title=Shenyang Olympic Sports Center Stadium |publisher=AXS Satow |accessdate=8 March 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130921053247/http://www.axscom.co.jp/portfolio/world/03011/index.php# |archive-date=2013-09-21 |dead-url=yes |df= }} as a replacement for [[Wulihe Stadium]]. It hosted [[Football at the 2008 Summer Olympics|football]] matches at the [[2008 Summer Olympics]].{{cite web |url = http://en.beijing2008.cn/venues/shy/index.shtml |title = Shenyang Olympic Sports Center Stadium |last = |first = |date = |website = |publisher = The Official Website of the Games of the XXIX Olympiad |accessdate = 19 September 2013 }} It is the home ground of the [[Shenyang Dongjin F.C.]] currently playing in the [[China League Two]]. In 2013 the stadium was the principal venue of the [[2013 National Games of China]] with the opening and closing ceremonies as well as the main athletic events.{{cite web|url=http://www.liaoning2013.com.cn/qycgyxm_new/cgyxmqycg_new/|title=您当前的位置|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=Twelfth National Games official website|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=19 September 2013}} The complex includes a 10,000-seat gymnasium, a 4,000-seat natatorium, and a 4,000-seat tennis field. ==External links== * [http://en.beijing2008.cn Beijing Olympics 2008 official website] * [http://www.liaoning2013.com.cn/ Liaoning 2013 China's Twelfth National Games official website] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{2008 Summer Olympics venues}} {{Olympic venues football}} {{coord|41.739037|123.457484|display=title|format=dms|type:landmark_scale:3000}} [[Category:Buildings and structures in Shenyang]] [[Category:Sport in Shenyang]] [[Category:Football venues in China]] [[Category:Athletics (track and field) venues in China]] [[Category:Venues of the 2008 Summer Olympics]] [[Category:Olympic football venues]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in China]] [[Category:Sports venues in Liaoning]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2007]] {{PRChina-sports-venue-stub}} {{2008-Olympic-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Distinguish|Sixfields Stadium}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2014}} {{Use British English|date=April 2014}} {{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Sixways Stadium | nickname = Sixways | image = [[File:Sixways SlickSystems East Stand.jpg|300px]] | caption = View of the East Stand to the east of the Stadium. | location = Warriors Way, Worcester WR3 8ZE<ref name=about/> | coordinates = {{coord|52|12|56|N|2|09|45|W|region:GB_type:landmark_source:dewiki|display=it}} | Stadium building commenced = 1998 | Ground opened = 1975 | renovated = 2008<ref name=about/> | surface = Limonta Max S Turf | tenants = [[Worcester Warriors]] | seating_capacity = 11,499<ref name=about/> }} '''Sixways Stadium''' is a [[stadium]] in [[Worcester]], [[England]]. It is currently used mostly for [[rugby union]] matches and is the home stadium of [[Worcester Warriors]]. The stadium is able to hold 11,499 with parking for 1,000 cars, Sixways has 60 modern meeting and event rooms .<ref name=about>{{cite web | url=http://www.warriors.co.uk/club/about.php | title=About Sixways Stadium | publisher=[[Worcester Warriors]] | accessdate=31 July 2013 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170705133124/http://www.warriors.co.uk/club/about.php | archivedate=5 July 2017 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> The ground opened 1975 and is located off junction 6 of the [[M5 motorway]], which splits into six directions, hence the name Sixways. The Stadium commenced building on the site of the old 3rd team pitch and club house after a lottery grant in 1998.
On 7 April 2016 it was announced that Sixways' pitch would be converted to the latest technology [[artificial grass]] ahead of the 2016–17 season. Sixways will become the third premiership venue with an artificial pitch after [[Barnet Copthall|Allianz Park]] and [[Kingston Park (stadium)|Kingston Park]] but the first to feature organic infill rather than rubber crumb.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.worcesternews.co.uk/sport/wrfc/news/14411062.Worcester_Warriors_to_install_synthetic_pitch_for_next_season/|title=Worcester Warriors to install synthetic pitch for next season|website=Worcester Warriors|publisher=Worcester News|last1=Berkely|first1=Geoff|accessdate=7 April 2016}}</ref>
== East Stand == The main focal point of Sixways Stadium is the magnificent East Stand which was completed in 2008 and has become one of the iconic images of Worcester on arrival in the city from the M5.
The multimillion-pound development on the east side of the stadium complex includes The PitchView Restaurant, The Business Club, The Duckworth Suite, The Worcester Suite, The Hindlip Suite and many boxes which are utlilised every day of the year. Below the stand is the Slick Systems Supporters bar area for fans to enjoy on matchdays and many food outlets and programme booths.
The entrance to the East Stand is through the main glass fronted club reception which is also home to the Sixways Store and Warriors Ticket Office which are open throughout the week.
== West Stand == The popular West Stand at Sixways Stadium has become a key gathering point for fans on matchdays as the most established stand at the home of the Warriors. The West Stand houses the Clubhouse Bar which offers a wide selection of draught and bottled beer. There is also a separate food counter serving hot snacks and in front of the bar is a large standing area to take in all the action.
The Sixways Premier Suites Upper and Lower are located to the south end of the stand and offer a large bar area and dance floor with a live band after every game. A lively and friendly sociable atmosphere is guaranteed to greet both home and away supporters after the action!
Above the Clubhouse Bar on the second floor is the International Bar which is full of rugby memorabilia past and present - and offers a fantastic view of all the action! Opposite is the Hallmark Bar which hosts an exclusive bar and dining area open to West Stand Debenture holders.
The West Stand is also home to the indoor training centre, changing rooms and rugby department offices which become the main training area for the Warriors during the week.
== South Stand == Standing proud behind the posts at Sixways Stadium, the South Stand is a busy and lively place to watch the action unfold on a big Warriors match day. The stand hosts 30 hospitality boxes for supporters to take in all the action over two floors with spacious bar areas to the rear.
The South Stand Terrace, in the middle of the stand, is a busy bar area where supporters can meet and enjoy food and drink before, during and after the kick-off at Warriors.
== North Stand == The all-seater North Stand gives supporters the chance to get close up to the action with easy access to bars to the left and right of the stand on match days. Popular with groups, the stand also hosts many of our Family Season Tickets. One of the most easily accessible areas of the stadium and with reasonably priced tickets, this stand often attracts many newcomers to the game eager to enjoy a Warriors fixture. Plans have been approved to increase the North Stand at Sixways Stadium to make it the same size as the Slick Systems Stand in years to come and complete an impressive looking front to the complex on arrival.
==Finals== The stadium hosted the [[2009–10 LV Cup]] final on 21 March 2010 between [[Northampton Saints]] and [[Gloucester Rugby|Gloucester]]. Northampton won 30–24.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/rugby_union/8571457.stm | title=Northampton 30-24 Gloucester | publisher=[[BBC]] | date=21 March 2010 | accessdate=31 July 2013}}</ref>
Sixways hosted the [[2011–12 LV Cup]] final on 18 March 2012 between [[Leicester Tigers]] and [[Northampton Saints]]. Leicester won 26–14.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.premiershiprugby.com/matchcentre/fixtures/1361.php | title=Leicester Tigers 26 - 14 Northampton Saints | publisher=premiershiprugby.com | date=18 March 2012 | accessdate=31 July 2013 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160107124338/http://www.premiershiprugby.com/matchcentre/fixtures/1361.php | archivedate=7 January 2016 | df=dmy-all }}</ref>
The stadium also hosted the [[2012–13 LV Cup]] final on 17 March 2013. [[Harlequin F.C.|Harlequins]] defeated [[Sale Sharks]] 32–14 in front of 8,100 spectators<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.premiershiprugby.com/matchcentre/fixtures/23547.php | title=Harlequins 32 - 14 Sale Sharks | publisher=premiershiprugby.com | date=17 March 2013 | accessdate=31 July 2013 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924081242/http://www.premiershiprugby.com/matchcentre/fixtures/23547.php | archivedate=24 September 2015 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> and gained a place in the [[2013–14 Heineken Cup]] as a result.
The stadium has also hosted the [[Britbowl]], the championship game of British [[American Football]] twice, in 2010 and 2016. [[London Blitz (American football)|London Blitz]] played in both finals, beating [[Coventry Jets]] 34-20 in 2010 and losing to [[London Warriors]] 36-15 in 2016.
== References == {{reflist|2}}
== External links == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20170705133124/http://www.warriors.co.uk/club/about.php About Sixways Stadium] * [http://www.sixwaysstadium.co.uk/ Events & Conferencing]
